snippet.title: Is the move to freeze Amnesty’s account, a witch hunt or valid crackdown? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla takes up the latest topic of the day which has gathered attention from everyone alike today. Amnesty International India has decided to halt all its operations in India, after the Centre froze their bank accounts. Amnesty International is a human rights Non-governmental organization, based out of the United Kingdom. The organization has been accused of receiving funds illegally and thus the government has frozen its accounts, under the Foreign Exchange Management Act violations.

While the Amnesty calls it a ‘witch-hunt’ by the Central government, the Ministry of Home Affairs has issued a statement and clarified that this is not a witch hunt but simply the rule of law which has to be followed by every organization. Problems have arisen for those organizations which have received foreign funding, especially during the NDA government’s rule in the country. To discuss and debate about the same, the panel on today’s Urban Debate includes BJP spokesperson Shweta Shalini, Suhas Chakma, Director at Rights and Risks Analysis Group and Gautam Mukherjee, Senior Journalist. 

Shweta Shalini states that ‘foreign funds are allowed in every organization, including NGOs, through a legal way.’ Amnesty under the garb of NGO was earning profits and doing anti-national activities. To contradict this, Suhas Chakma states that we have a situation where political parties, that run the country, can receive foreign funds, but NGOs are subjected to investigations.

snippet.title: Will the states end up implementing the new farm laws? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla talks about the farm reform row. The farm laws right from the beginning saw a massive protest, not just by the farmers across the country, but also by the oppositions. According to the opposition ministers, these farm laws were not made keeping in mind the farmers, as they have no guarantee of the MSP. The farmers continue to stage protests across the states, even though these bills have received President’s assent and have now become laws. The Shiromani Akali Dal has broken the 23-year-old alliance with the NDA government and Harsimrat Kaur Badal has also resigned because of these farm bills. 

However, opposition parties continue to fight and the Congress government in Punjab has said that they will not implement the farm bills in the state and that they are planning to knock the doors of the top court against three legislations. While one of the Kerala MP from Thrissur has already taken the matter to the SC, the government adds that they will also take up the matter in the court as well.

But do the states have an option of not implementing these farm laws? To get a legal perspective on this matter, Sidharth Luthra presents a clear picture in front of us. Former Additional Solicitor General Sidharth Luthra adds that there really is not much of a choice that is left with the states, given that the powers balance between state and the centre.

snippet.title: How will India tackle the challenge of vaccinating a billion people? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, today we take up the challenges of COVID-19 vaccination for a billion people. Adar Poonawalla, the Chief Executive Officer of the Serum Institute of India, which is conducting trials of the COVID-19 vaccine. Adar Poonawalla on Saturday raised questions regarding the country’s plan to produce and distribute shots against the coronavirus disease.

Adar Poonawalla stated that the government needs a budget of 80,000 crores and a plan to deliver the process of vaccinating a billion people.

Phase 3 trials of the vaccine have been developed by Oxford University and British pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca, the vaccine is underway in India as part of a production and testing deal with the Pune-based Serum Institute of India (SII). Adar Poonawalla tweeted over how the government of India has to manage a fund of 80,000 crores available, over the next one year. He further added that is what the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare needs to buy and distribute the vaccine to everyone in India. This is the next concerning the challenge we need to tackle. He asked the question because as a country, India needs to plan and guide the vaccine manufacturers both in India and overseas to service the needs of our country in terms of procurement and distribution.

Sujata Rao, Former Health Secretary says, By the time the COVID-19 vaccine really gets into the market, it is quite possible the caseload might reduce and we may be getting into herd immunity. In which case, the uptake of the vaccine by the people might be problematic,”.

snippet.title: With the SAD breaking out of alliance, can the NDA afford to lose any more allies? |The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Afrida Ali talks about the ending of a 23 –year-old alliance between the Shiromani Akali Dal and the NDA. The move comes in after the SAD leader Harsimrat Badal resigned from her post over the protests against farm bills. 

The SAD says that the alliance has ended over centre’s refusal to give legislative guarantees to protect MSP. The highest decision-making body of the Shiromani Akali Dal decided late last night to exit the alliance. To discuss and analyze the exit of SAD, the panel includes Tuhin Sinha, BJP Spokesperson, Neerja Chowdhury, senior journalist and Maheshinder Singh Grewal of SAD. 

Maheshinder Singh Grewal stated that it is very unfortunate that Punjab government never took state peasantry and Punjabis into confidence about the going on meetings of the NDA government. He further adds that SAD has not been there only for the power in Punjab, and if the party only wanted power, it would have been in power since 1992. On being asked if the NDA can afford to lose any more alliance, given that this is the third ally to quit, Tuhin Sinha states that the decision of SAD to pull out is because of some misunderstanding.

snippet.title: Farmers protest across India; Will Government take cognizance of their demands? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla talks about the Bharat Bandh and the farmer protest that took place in the country today. A massive Rail Roko was witnessed in Punjab. The farm protests come in line with the farm bills that have been passed in the Lok Sabha in the last week, even after facing a massive criticism from the opposition. While the opposition stated that the farm bills are not in favour of the farmers, the ruling government has been bent on the fact that they are for the betterment of the farmers. 

Shama Mohamed states that the BJP does not see farmers as humans. It is their protest and we are supporting them. My question to the government is why not put MSP in the bill? Avik Saha, National Convenor of Jai Kisan Andolan further adds that “it looks like there were protests at 20,000 sites today and about 20 lakh farmers were out on the streets today.” The government refuses to understand the requirement of the farmers and is going on legislating at breakneck speed.

BJP member Shivam Chhabra contradicts this statement by saying that poor propaganda is being run by the opposition for trying to oppose a bill which is progressive. They have been trying to persuade the farmers saying there is some serious issue regarding the MSP of the crops.

snippet.title: Bihar elections 2020 dates out; Will polls amid COVID impact political parties? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla takes up the Bihar elections topic and discusses how the elections will be held amidst the pandemic. Bihar is the first state which will be conducting elections amidst the pandemic and the Chief Election Commissioner has announced the dates and has also made it clear that the elections will be conducted in three phases. 

Will the COVID-19 norms make it more challenging to take the message to the voters of the work that the political party has done? Tanvi Shukla asks Syed Afzal Abbas of JDU party. Chitranjan Gagan states that the people of Bihar have made up their mind to get freedom from Nitish Kumar government. He further adds that Tejashwi Yadav will become the next Chief Minister of Bihar. Nitish Kumar has been the CM of the state for the last 15 years.  

Nikhil Anand adds that BJP is happy that elections are a part of the democratic process and it should take place on time. BJP is surprised that RJD wants to come to power on a hollow note. We are sure we will come to power, adds Nikhil Anand.

snippet.title: Anushka-Sunil Gavaskar controversy; Was his remark sexist or misunderstood? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla takes up the war of words that broke out between veteran cricketer Sunil Gavaskar and actor Anushka Sharma. Recently, commentator and cricketer Sunil Gavaskar commented on Virat Kohli’s performance, but he went a step ahead and dragged his wife in the conversation and the actor did not take it well.

Anushka Sharma responded to Sunil Gavaskar asking as to why she was being dragged in the talks of cricket. Sunil Gavaskar is known to be very vocal when it comes to critiquing but there has to be a line to everything that one says. Sunil Gavaskar stated that Virat Kohli could have performed better if only he would have focused on the practice. The cricketer has only faced Anushka’s bowling in the lockdown. Fans of both Anushka Sharma and Virat Kohli have expressed resentment to this.

RJ Stutee Ghosh states that while we know the saying that behind every successful man, there is a woman, seems like the woman is there so she can be blamed when he is not successful and that Anushka Sharma is well within her rights to be offended.

snippet.title: Six months since lockdown, Are crores of small businesses struggling to survive? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate, We talk about our country's financial state, our country's economy, our future and our jobs. It has been six months since the lockdown was announced and now some businesses have begun, and shops and malls have started operating. But in many cities and towns of our country, they remain empty. They are selling goods, clothes and daily essentials but they remain empty. Because people are not buying, they are worried about having another salary cut or job loss.

Are crores of small businesses struggling to survive? Is there enough financial support available for small businesses? Should Centre bring more stimulus for small businesses? And with the load payment relief ending now, will more small businesses default? Listen in!

snippet.title: Top Bollywood stars on NCB's radar, A witch-hunt or first step to cleanup? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate, One of the biggest talking points in our country has been the Narcotics Control Bureau's (NCB) investigation into the drug links in Bollywood.

It started off with late actor Sushant Singh Rajput's case and then investigation into Rhea Chakraborty, her brother Showik Chakraborty and her manager, and then the net widened. The Narcotics Control Bureau's (NCB) case is not going to be limited to Rhea Chakraborty.

One after the other, big Bollywood names, from designers to talent managers to big actors and A-listers are now being summoned by the Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB). 

Deepika Padukone has been asked to appear before the Narcotics Control Bureau's (NCB) on September 26th. Rakul Preet is also likely to join the NCB probe on September 25th. Sara Ali Khan has also been summoned September 26th. Designer Simone has already been questioned by the Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) for 5 hours. There are several more who are already being questioned.

Is this a witch-hunt or the first step to cleanup? Listen in!

snippet.title: 1st women officers deployed on warships; Women making history in 2020 | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla speaks exclusively to Sub Lt Kumodini Tyani and Sub Lt Riti Singh, first women officers to be deployed on warships. For the first time, women tacticians will work on navy Warcraft. Along with being mission observers for helicopters, these women will also help in marking out, tracking, and navigating the enemies
Sub Lieutenant Singh says, ‘This is happening for the first time. We are getting to make history. Our training is very difficult and we were trained both mentally and physically. It also included an eight months course, but, all our efforts are finally paid off’.

snippet.title: Bills pass without Opposition's consent; Are laws without debate becoming a norm? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla talks about a topic which has caught everyone’s attention in the last few days. The Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha sessions have ended today. Over 16 different legislations, bills and amendments were passed in the Parliament.

These bills were passed in the last two days when the opposition parties had boycotted the session. This means that 16 legislations were passed without comprehensive discussions, debates or proper participation of all parties.

Should debate legislation be acceptable in a thriving parliamentary democracy?

Former Lok Sabha MP Kalikesh Singh says, ‘To pass such important legislation without discussion, debate, or keeping in view the opposition's different perspective, is a sad thing for democracy. But it isn’t new’. While CPI’s Dinesh Varshney says, ‘It is a murder of democracy. The people of India have been left in the lurch to suffer from generations to generations’.

WATCH!

#DebatelessLegislations #MonsoonSession #ParliamentSession

snippet.title: In-depth details of India-China meet, Are they staring at a prolonged standoff? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss the high-level meeting of the commanders of India and China. The talks started yesterday and lasted for about 12 hours. A joint statement may be issued by India-China. Are we looking a prolonged standoff and there can be a breakthrough? 

Chinese have to demonstrate that they mean each & every line that is being spoken. They're the ones who have broken the confidence, says Lt Gen PJS Pannu (Retd), Former Deputy Chief IDS & Former Commander 14 Corps on the joint statement issued by India & China. 

Chinese intrusions reflect the events leading up to the 1962 conflict & up to Kargil. One should brace themselves to deal with the new China which will include both territorial aggression & cyber attacks says Maroof Raza, Strategic Affairs Expert. The month of October is crucial as many talks will be taking place. 

#IndiaChinaStandoff

snippet.title: Farm Bills debate escalates, Is there merit in opposition's charge? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss the farm bills debate escalation. She explains their demands, shares details on what unfolded in the last 2-days with reference to the Farmers Bill 2020 & questions the opposition's demand merit. 

When there's a demand for division, Chair has no other option; it has to order division. After division has been asked, Chairman can't go back to voice vote,” says PDT Achary, Former Secretary-General, Lok Sabha. 

As far as these #FarmBills2020 is concerned, these momentous bills impact the lives of our Farmers, the backbone of India's democracy and they thus had high expectations says Bishwajit Bhattacharya, Former ASG. The circumstances in which the bill had been passed on that day, they are convinced there was no illegality. At no point of time did the Deputy Speaker categorically deny division of vote until he was virtually attacked,” says Tuhin Sinha.

#FarmersBill2020

snippet.title: COVID cases are on the rise, but schools want to re-open? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, most governments around the world have temporarily closed educational institutions in an attempt to contain the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.

These nationwide closures are impacting hundreds of millions of students. Several other countries have implemented localized closures impacting millions of additional learners.

AAP leader Dr Ajoy Kumar says that 'for Delhi, we need to make sure we don’t put any child’s life at risk. The government of India’s guidelines are fancy. Adults are not doing it and you expect the children too!'

“It’s easy to put in SOPs. If social distancing is maintained and half the number of children sit in class, where does the other half go? It is necessary to go into minute details and see if the school has the capacity to accommodate these children,” says NCP Clyde Crasto. 
Watch!

snippet.title: Why is Congress opposing 'Farm sector reforms'? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Prime Minister Narendra Modi's assurance to the farmers comes on the backdrop of an ongoing ruckus over the farm bills, which were passed in the Rajya Sabha on Sunday. The Opposition benches have been protesting against the bills calling them 'anti-farmer'. 

Former Finance Minister P Chidambaram also asked how the government was planning to guarantee a minimum support price to farmers. Congress leader Rahul Gandhi also took to Twitter and blamed the government for the state of the economy as well as for passing the 'black agriculture laws'. 

Congress Dr Shama Mohamed says, 'By brute force, the bill was passed in Lok Sabha. In Rajya Sabha, no answers were given to oppositions’ questions, nor was there division of vote. If Govt is confident that they're right, why not send it to a select committee?'

#FarmBill2020

snippet.title: IPL 2020:No home ground, No spectators, Will this year's tournament be different?| The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, IPL tournament for this year is about to start. It was delayed by several months, but there is a lot of excitement building up. Countdown to the most unique edition of the IPL 2020 begins. With no home ground, no glitz, no spectators, IPL 2020 is going to be Cricket's most unusual event. How it is going to be different this time?  

Former India International Cricketer Hemang Badani says, "BCCI has tried to tighten everything but there's always an element of doubt with players. The side that's ready to adapt & make those changes, will be the side that will do well."

"80-90% of IPL players are not used to bio-bubbles. They will be befuddled by the fact that for 1-2 weeks without any company except our own, but for a couple of months it will be difficult," says the Sports Commentator Charu Sharma.

snippet.title: Harsimrat Kaur Badal on why she resigned from ministerial post? | EXCLUSIVE | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Farmers are protesting against all three 'Farm Bills', it’s the provisions of the first one that particularly bothers them. The Bill aims to create an ecosystem which allows farmers to trade their produce outside the markets or ‘mandis’ notified under the various state agricultural produce market laws (state APMC Acts). It also allows ‘barrier-free’ intra-state and inter-state trade of farmers’ produce outside state APMCs. 

Union Minister Harsimrat Kaur Badal resigned after Lok Sabha passed bills meant to replace the agriculture ordinances. Her resignation comes amid intense protests in Punjab and Harayana over the legislations.

Watch the Member of the Lok Sabha Harsimrat Kaur Badal in an exclusive conversation over 'Farmers' Bill'

"We stand with the farmers of the Nation and will go to whatever steps we have to go to make them feel that their future is secure with this bill, and the bill works in their favour," says Harsimrat Kaur Badal.

Watch!

snippet.title: Is India supporting its COVID-19 frontline warriors? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Frontline warrior in the battle against COVID-19 has almost taken the fight and certainly going to continue for another year. These warriors are fighting day and night against the pandemic without thinking about themselves or their families and are out on the ground in our service. 

Indian Medical Association has accused the Centre of indifference towards frontline COVID warriors saying that 382 doctors who died due to COVID-19 should be treated as martyrs. What can we as a nation do to help our frontline warriors? 

Tanvi Shukla questions Congress Dr Shama Mohamed, asks, " What have the Congress-ruled states done to take care of our health care workers & medical professionals?"

snippet.title: UAPA law failed to prosecute or not used right? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Interesting data was shared in a Parliament by the government regarding the "Anti-terror law", The UAPA law. The "Anti-terror law" was amended last year. These changes were brought in to counter the terrorism and it will help the agencies further. but in the last 2 years, 3,005 cases have been filed and only 821 charge sheets. Is Centre's data indicative that anti-terror law is being misused?

Delhi Former Commissioner of Police TR Kakkar says "When cases of this nature occur, first thing is to bring around peace & for that, you register these cases if you've proof. When you say 3,000 cases filed, it doesn't mean those cases have been closed."

#AntiTerrorLaw

snippet.title: Should regulations be placed on 'Digital media' platforms? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Once something is uploaded on Social Media, it circulates & gets viral very quickly. There perhaps needs to be regulations and that's the government's order. What should be the rules and regulations for digital media, a new age media for all kinds of professions?

Supreme Court Senior Advocate Sanjay Hegde says "Under the IT Act, you can take out specific content. You cannot regulate it, you can do regular policing. The affidavit, in this case, is being slightly economical with the truth when it's saying there is no regulation & SC must step in to regulate."

Watch!

snippet.title: Government's response on migrants crisis; Fake news blamed for exodus? The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, As the lockdown hit the country, the situation for migrant workers did not improve at all. Despite the assurance from the Centre and state government. Until the decision was made to start the trains for migrant workers and then some state government buses and then we reached a point where each single migrant worker who wanted to go home in some of the other manners reached home. Is it fair to blame fake news for triggering migrant exodus?

Tanvi Shukla explains what entails the migrant crisis & government's response to it in the Parliament saying, 'Fake News triggered migrants exodus' 

NCP's Mahesh Tapase over migrant crisis says "How much money the government has collected from states? Government can't tell how many people died saying 'we don't have central agencies to collate data'. These kinds of answers are not warranted. We want clear answers"

snippet.title: Delhi riots chargesheet filed in court, Is probe being one sided? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, The large group of activist held a news briefing along with a few journalists to accuse the Delhi Police of a partial probe. This in the light of fact that JNU student and activist Umar Khalid has been arrested by the Delhi Police in reference to the Delhi riots. Delhi Police filing the charge-sheet in this one specific case. Where 15 of the 20 have been arrested so far and has named as accused. 

Mirror Now accessed the details of the charge sheet filed by the police today in Delhi riots case. Tanvi Shukla explains the scale of the investigation being carried out in the case & asks, Is Delhi Police being selective?

Tanvi Shukla questions Former IPS officer Yashovardhan Azad over Delhi riots and asks Is there merit to the charge that the investigation is biased or focused on one side, probably the side that was protesting against the CAA?

#DelhiRiots

snippet.title: Big takeaways from DM Rajnath Singh's statement; Shift in policy towards China? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss India's clear shift in policy towards China. 5 big takeaways from Defence Minister Rajnath Singh's statement explained. There is a definitive change in the way the government will handle the China situation. It was an ambiguous response that came from the Government. 

The government of India has said that they are ready for any eventuality though they want to take the path of peace and dialogue. The faceoff with China is very different. The Line of Actual Control in Arunachal Pradesh has seen Chinese movement and the Indian troops have moved 20 km further. 

Senior Editor Manu Pubby also gives a sense of the on-ground situation since the Defence & foreign Minister's meetings. There is an uneasy calm. Both sides are waiting on core commander level talks to happen. 

#IndiaChinaFaceOff

snippet.title: FB 'Insider's' sensational disclosure, Fake accounts used to influence elections? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss the charges against Facebook. Insider exposes Facebook say they let fake accounts influence elections. The uses & abuse of social media platforms are also highlighted. Buzzfeed brought to us a story of a whistle-blower, Sophie Zhang, an ex-employee from Facebook who in her memo explained how governments, political parties, used Facebook to influence voters & elections. 

Media Editor Craig Silverman says the whistle-blower came across repeated examples of cases whereof Govts & heads of states being linked to the network of fake accounts, that would harass opposition figures through comments, amplify false information or propaganda. The insider's claims are linked to Delhi elections. A network was used to politically affect the elections. 

Facebook doesn't have the capacity because it hasn't invested enough in addressing hate speech, co-ordinated attacks, political interference. It needs to be regulated because it is a significant company here, says Nikhil Pahwa, Founder of MediaNama.com.

snippet.title: Lok Sabha passes the Essential Commodities Bill, Are ordinances anti-farmer? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss, the farmer ordinance bill proposed in the Parliament and the protests thereafter. Lok Sabha has now passed the contentious Essential Commodities, Bill. Why are farmers protesting the ordinances? Are the ordinances anti-farmer?

The farmers have protested in Punjab, Haryana and North-Eastern States. According to them, their requests have not been considered. This bill will impact their Minimum Support Price (MSP) privilege. Rakesh Tikait of Bharatiya Kisan Union says the private mandis will shut down after 2 years on which tax has to be paid. The farmers stocking capacity is also an issue which is not addressed in the bill. This is objectionable.  

As per the 7th schedule of the Constitution, the agriculture & Mandis are state subject.  The promulgation of an ordinance of GOI without taking into consideration the State is questionable says Professor Gourav Vallabh of Congress.

#FarmersProtest #EssentialCommoditiesBill

snippet.title: Government opposes plea filed in Delhi HC; Should India legalise same-sex marriage? The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla she explains the arguments made by the govt in the court for same-sex marriage and questions, should India legalise same-sex marriage? The government opposed the plea filed in Delhi High Court seeking recognition of same-sex marriage.

This is not about gay marriage, it is about consenting adults deciding to take their relationship to the next stage. This has far-reaching responses says Equal Rights Activist Harish Iyer. All that the govt had to tell the Supreme Court today is that 'yes we agree that a lot of changes will have to be made & let's do that'

Throughout India, we've many indigenous traditions which accommodate diverse LGBTQI community as part of traditions. What makes the Solicitor General think that this is a kind of anti-Hindu move?

#SameSexMarriage

snippet.title: Chinese firm Zhenhua caught tracking India's data, Is it a concern? The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss China's Zhenhua dragnet. Over 10,000 Indians, including personalities from politics, business, judiciary, media, sportspersons, and even crime-accused are being tracked by a big data firm linked to the Chinese government. Cyber Security Expert Ritesh Bhatia explains what is the Chinese firm Zhenhua doing and if there should be any concern. 

He says that the Zhenhua collects massive documents and information about key personalities. Zhenhua also tracks digital footprints of these personalities, he further adds. Information library is created from various sources. It also has data on people and their relations with various institutions. Data collected by this firm can also be used to access the dark web and run multiple algorithms. 

Every govt does these kinds of practices, the issue is, we're ignoring it at a massive scale. Concern should be how they're able to acquire data. If they're acquiring it by buying it from Indian companies, that is important.

#ZhenhuaData

snippet.title: Is Umar Khalid's arrest by Delhi Police 'political'? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss former JNU student leader Umar Khalid's arrest in the Delhi riots case. He has been sent to 10-days police custody. Stringent charges have been levelled against Umar Khalid. He has been booked under various Sections of UAPA such as violence, conspiracy, terrorist activities and more. 

The question is not of the timing of the arrest as it is not appropriate to judge this issue. The question that needs to be asked is the necessity & effect of the arrest. Advocate Ashish Dixit questions, the charge sheet is ready and it's going to be submitted this week, then why go for this arrest, unless there's another motive?

#UmarKhalidArrested

snippet.title: Will India need to resort to other methods while the 5 point consensus is signed? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla talks about the LAC standoff issue between India and China. China continues to provoke India and the result is a five-month-long standoff. A meeting between India’s External Minister and his counterpart from China was the part of a meeting in Moscow and both the parties have decided on the 5 point consensus on how to take the situation forward. According to the consensus, the differences will not be allowed to become a dispute. Both sides will abide by the existing agreements and that India and China will agree to continue with dialogue. Some of the questions that Tanvi Shukla addresses today include ‘will the latest talks lead to a breakthrough?’ ‘Are we headed for an armed conflict with China?’
Snehesh Philip, Senior Associate Editor at The Print states that statements have come from China talking about peace. But I am sceptical because they do the exact opposite of what they say. We will have to wait for the words to turn into action. He further adds that from a military perspective we shouldn’t let our guards down, we should be prepared. Jayadeva Ranade, Former Additional Secretary, adds that the fact there was a meeting between the two foreign ministers, to a very limited extent, is a positive sign. My suspicion is that China is doing this to buy time for something else they have planned.
Lt Gen DS Hooda states that he doesn’t see a quick and early resolution. There’s nothing new in the 5-point consensus too. It’s the same old chatter. We have to keep our powder dry.

snippet.title: Should we blame the ministers or citizens for neglecting norms? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla focuses on the COVID-19 pandemic which is becoming a worrisome situation for India. India has now become the second country which is the worst hit by the COVID-19. The country is witnessing a surge in the number of cases partially because the number of testing has gone higher but also because people have forgotten the protocols that were put in place for everyone’s safety. Mumbai is seeing a spike again in the number of COVID-19 cases.

If one person gets it in the household, everybody is likely to get it within the incubation period of 5-7 days. We need to maintain strict isolation, says Dr Pradeep Banandur. Dr Sanjeev Bagai adds to this by saying every asymptomatic person might be a carrier and harbourer for this. The summer has made no impact on it either, says Dr Sanjeev Bagai.

Mahesh Tapase, NCP Spokesperson states that we as citizens have to realize that we are living in the time of COVID and we should change our mindset and behaviour. Apart from the negligence on the part of citizens, a great number of violations come from the VVIPs, who exploit their status accordingly. Tanvi asks Congress’ Dr Sravan Dasoju that despite witnessing a high number of cases amongst politicians, why are they not learning the lesson and following the norms? She also questions Karnataka’s BJP leader Vivek Reddy asking that we haven’t even officially entered the election season in West Bengal and here the state BJP Chief is holding rallies and telling them that COVID has gone.

Dr Sanjeev Bagai adds to this by saying every asymptomatic person might be a carrier and harbourer for this. The summer has made no impact on it either, says Dr Sanjeev Bagai.

Mahesh Tapase, NCP Spokesperson states that we as citizens have to realize that we are living in the time of COVID and we should change our mindset and behaviour. Apart from the negligence on the part of citizens, a great number of violations come from the VVIPs, who exploit their status accordingly. Tanvi asks Congress’ Dr Sravan Dasoju that despite witnessing a high number of cases amongst politicians, why are they not learning the lesson and following the norms? She also questions Karnataka’s BJP leader Vivek Reddy asking that we haven’t even officially entered the election season in West Bengal and here the state BJP Chief is holding rallies and telling them that COVID has gone.

snippet.title: How many more lives will it cost to normalize suicide conversations? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla talks about the most important and yet most under-discussed topic of all time, suicide. The conversation around suicide is still considered a taboo especially if it happens because of depression or any other mental condition. It is the World Suicide Prevention Day and it is important that this conversation should take place.

2020 is definitely one of the toughest years that we have seen, given the pandemic that broke and put everything to a halt. The year has also witnessed some great losses and it is thus important to speak up about our Mental Health and that of others. 1,39,123 people died by suicide in India in 2019. Over 10,000 students committed suicide in the year 2019, the highest in 25 years. With COVID-19 impacting lives across the globe, there is a greater need to talk about the impact of it on Mental Health.

snippet.title: Pradhan Mantri Kisan Gareeb Kalyan Yojna, a scheme or a scam? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla talks about the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Gareeb Kalyan Yojna. The scheme essentially is to help the small and marginal farmers. The central government scheme says that every four months two thousand rupees will be credited in the account of the farmers. A scam in regards to this scheme has been unearthed in Tamil Nadu, a scam which was being carried on in thirteen different districts. 

The farmers who were not eligible for the scheme also went ahead and applied for the scheme. A bribe was paid for it to the middlemen. A sum of 500 Rs was given to the middlemen, in order to obtain a sum of Rs 6,000. The computer operators created accounts of these not eligible people and colluded with the government officials

snippet.title: Is there a need to revive the economy, does the government have a strategy for it? |The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla takes up the most important topic and one that has everyone’s eyes fixed to, that is the Economy. The Coronavirus pandemic which broke in the country in the month of March has engulfed everyone in its claw including the economy. The economy has taken the worst hit this year with GDP’s Q1 crushing down to -23.9%. But what does a negative GDP means to you? Does the government have a strategy to revive the economy? Is there a need for a fresh stimulus package? Has the government’s response to the economic crisis been appropriate?

Dr Ajay Dua, Former Commerce Secretary stated that while going forward, the government needs to shed its inhibitions and not merely talk of a Rs 20 trillion package. What we need now is for the government to not worry too much about its fiscal deficit.

Economist Ramakumar adds that when the lockdown began, the Indian economy was highly vulnerable, the lockdown which was informed by a poor strategy, wreaked havoc after March. Madan Sabnavis, another economist states because of the uncertainty you won’t be able to take any consumption decisions which is going to affect businesses. They will not be able to invest unless they see demand coming through.

snippet.title: Will the need for armed conflict with China arise,  Is India prepared for it? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla takes up the much-debated and discussed topic of India China standoff. She further asks that are we headed towards an armed conflict with China? After multiple failed attempts at talks, can China be trusted? Why is China repeatedly provoking its neighbours? Can the international community rein in China? 

Former Indian Army Chief, General VP Malik states that it’s a kind of a razor’s edge situation and we have to be prepared for escalation. Economic Times Senior Editor Manu Pubby states that the concern now is that if this incident happens in other areas of the Chushul sector, it could lead to some escalation, beyond what we have seen in the past.

Maroof Raza, Strategic Affairs Expert mentions that we can finally identify what is our threshold of being pushed by the Chinese are. He further adds that according to him, we are reaching that threshold. Maroof Raza further goes on to mention that the myth of resolving issues with diplomatic dialogue is finally broken. Vishnu Prakash, Former Ambassador states that China is trying to needle India. He goes on to say that the posture that we have adopted is the right one. If push comes to shove, we are capable of inflicting a cost.

snippet.title: Rhea Chakraborty arrested by NCB; What are the charges leveled against her? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Rhea Chakraborty's arrest is a massive development in the Sushant Singh Rajput case. The Narcotics Control Bureau has arrested her for procuring drugs. It is reportedly stated that she is supposed to be under the judicial custody of the Narcotics Control Bureau. 

Mirror Now has accessed the remand copy that states that Rhea Chakraborty was actively involved in the drug syndicate. Yashovardhan Azad, former IPS officer explains how the Narcotics Control Bureau's investigation is on a different trajectory. He further adds, if the aim of the Narcotics Control Bureau, as they say, is to do clean up of Bollywood, then this certainly was not the right time. The Enforcement Directorate case has fallen flat and abetment to suicide is in tatters now.

Sanjay Hedge, a senior advocate, explains how the entire case is based on WhatsApp chats, he further adds that he has serious doubts, as to the evidentiary value of WhatsApp chat. He says that there are no Supreme Court judgments on the point. He also talks about how there is no serious investigation done on the ground.

#RheaChakraborty #RheaArrested #RheaChakrabortyArrested

snippet.title: COVID Unlocking Phase needs to be taken seriously, will people agree? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla discusses the COVID unlocking phase with a team of Doctors, trying to understand the current situation. The COVID-19 pandemic which broke in the month of March has engulfed not just the people but the economy as well. 

Dr Gautam Bhansali, member of the Maharashtra COVID19 task force states that with the unlocking and festivals, the cases have increased. He further adds that if there has been an increase in the number of cases, the number of tests being conducted in a day have also gone up. Another doctor, Dr SK Sarin states that the reason we are going to see more cases is that there is a spread of the virus via asymptomatic people. Everyone should thus try and get tested. He further adds that we have a long way to go in September.  


Dr Vijay D’Silva states that the solution for this pandemic lies in the hands of the people. They have to be more disciplined and wear masks and maintain social distancing. On speaking with AIIMS director Dr Randeep Guleria, it’s discovered that there is a bit of COVID behaviour fatigue. People have let their guards down. A strategy is needed to revitalize, re-energize people to go back to following the norms.

snippet.title: 85 days after Sushant Singh Rajput's death; What is the status of the ED probe? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, after 85 days since Sushant Singh Rajput's death, there are various leads to the case that are probing the drug link and the financial angle. Three investigation agencies and a million theories are out in the open, but hyperventilating hysteria does not get justice?

Tanvi Shukla looks at the probe so far and breaks down all the facts on record. The Enforcement Directorate is looking to the money laundering aspect in the case. The Enforcement Directorate started its probe before the CBI. So what is the status of the probe by the Enforcement Directorate?

Narcotics Control Bureau is the only agency that has made arrests in the case so far. Dr. NC Asthana, Former DGP, says that the channels reporting in such a vociferous manner, they have been violating the Supreme Court orders and tormenting the poor girl. Senior Supreme Court Advocate, Kailash Vasdev explains what happens to cases when there are so many leaks, theories, public conversations, and media trials.

snippet.title: Teachers’ Day Celebrations amidst the new normal | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate, Teacher’s Day is celebrated in a very special way. Mirror Now’s Aarti Subramanian speaks to a panel of teachers about their experience of shifting to the online mode of conducting classes and the challenges that they have faced.

Anuradha Joshi, a panellist expresses that her online teaching journey so far has been tough and that they are trying to make a connection with the children. The transition, however, was smooth for Avnita Bir, whose school has been trying to bring the transition from a long time now. The teachers waded in with the technologies and marched in to help the children, even when the world was at a standstill.

snippet.title: NCB arrests two in connection with drug link, Will Rhea Chakraborty be next? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate, Actor Rhea Chakraborty's brother Showik Chakraborty and Sushant Singh Rajput's house manager Samuel Miranda have been arrested. The former paper work is under way. Mirror Now accessed the remand copy submitted by Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) in the court today. In the remand copy, NCB has claimed that Basit Parihar has revealed his connections with Showik Chakraborty and Samuel Miranda. 

Santia Gora and Alok Singh explains the drug links that have emerged in the case till now.

Mirror Now's Managing Editor Vinay Tewari says that the drug cartel supply is a very organised racket & it can't be carried out unless those cartels have involvement of somebody very senior. The ease at which it happens tells you, that it has been never handled effectively

snippet.title: Maharashtra's COVID jumbo failure in Pune, Why no action taken yet? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Sahar Zaman, Worst nightmare for Pune city. The total number of COVID positive cases in the Pune has surpassed the total number of what Mumbai and Delhi ever reported. Currently, the figure reported is 1.86 lakhs of positive cases. There is an absolute collapse in the health infrastructure. The State Government and the local city administration had promised Jumbo facility that would be prepared out of three of them, one is operational. 

Wife of the journalist who died at Pune's Jumbo facility, Sheetal Raikar share her case over the Pune COVID crisis, she says "My husband is a victim of this damaged system. There was no proper treatment. There was a lot of miscommunication. They did not even provide him with the tiffin that we sent over."    

Maharashtra COVID-19 taskforce member Dr Shashank Joshi says that If the facilities are not up to the mark, they shouldn’t be functioning in the first place. After 4 months, we are back to square 1, where people have to run from pillar to post.

#PuneCoronaCrisis

snippet.title: Supreme Court on loan moratorium; Should relief for repaying EMIs be extended? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Afrida Rahman Ali, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman held a meeting with the heads of banks & NBFCs to review the implementation of one-time debt recast for resolution of COVID-19 related stress in bank loans. Finance Minister urged them to lend actively during the upcoming festive season.

Supreme Court heard a batch of petitions seeking an interest waiver on loan moratorium. Afrida Rahman Ali shares all the updates on what was observed in the court. 

If there is no interest waiver, what do borrowers get in terms of relief? Afrida Rahman Ali questions MSME India President  Mukesh Mohan Gupta. 

BJP spokeperson Vishwas Pathak says "This government is open to relaxations for specific cases. However, it can't be blanket. If you're an honest borrower with a good track record, this moratorium period can go even up to 2-years."


Watch!

If there is no interest waiver, what do borrowers get in terms of relief? Afrida Rahman Ali questions MSME India President  Mukesh Mohan Gupta. 

BJP spokeperson Vishwas Pathak says "This government is open to relaxations for specific cases. However, it can't be blanket. If you're an honest borrower with a good track record, this moratorium period can go even up to 2-years."

snippet.title: Rise in Drug abuse amid Corona, Not just celebs but your child is a target too? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Sahar Zaman, Two separate Drug racket cases which are being investigated in the country. 1: The Karnakata drug racket case which has been busted. 2: The arrest have been made from Mumbai, Goa and federal agency is still trying to connect the dots which is largely now been called the 'Bollywood drug cartel.' In both these cases, the agency has chosen to say that they are going to be nabbing high profile names. This is rich, famous, celebrity names, names connected to politicians as well. But is that the right spectrum to view it through? Is it always about the rich & high-profiles? Do we need to worry about us as ordinary middle-class people? How this affects us? There is increased of drug mafias across the country, there is a possibility that it rings much closer at our own home.   

Recovering Drug Addict shares view on how she overcome her addiction, she says "Drugs are easily available in India. But there is a lot of taboo attached to addiction. I have to hide my identity & talk about it because it is still not accepted as a problem."   

#DrugAbuse

snippet.title: Is denying MPs right to question the government, undemocratic? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate today, Afrida Rahman Ali discusses a highly contentious issue of a decision that has been taken by the government with regards to the monsoon session of Parliament.  The Lok Sabha secretariat has made an official release for the schedule of the monsoon session and surprisingly, it does not have the question hour, due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  This decision has resulted in many disputes and political debates.

What is the question hour? Is denying MPs the right to question the government, undemocratic?

‘If COVID-19 is the reason then why have the session at all? If it is to prevent people from getting infected then what's the guarantee that they'll be at maximum danger during the question hour & rest of the day, they'll be fine’ says, Senior Journalist, Javed Mansari

While, RS MP CPI, Binoy Viswam says, ‘The government is angry with the questions. People are dying on the streets, this government has failed everywhere and they can't claim it has any concern for the poor’, Congress’ Spokesperson question, ‘The question hour is the soul of democracy. When the Parliament can run for 4 hours then why can't there be a question hour?

WATCH!

snippet.title: Only 33% food provided to migrants; Have States failed to feed poor & jobless? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, Sahar Zaman talks about the food that was promised to the poor migrants amid the COVID-19 pandemic crisis. The Central Government had promised 5kg foodgrains to migrants. However, only 33% of grains were distributed by States.

Bihar, Telangana, Tamil Nadu, Assam, Rajasthan and many other states have awfully failed to allot said food. Only Odisha is one such state which managed to give almost all the foodgrains meant under the scheme.

Have states failed to feed the poor and jobless?

‘Announcement without a background planning & a blueprint would have always led to this. System of delivery from Central Government godowns & its picking by States hasn't been seamless’ says, JKA Convenor, Avik Saha.

While Congress’ Charan Sapra says, ‘33% usage is a worrisome situation for the entire country. 80% of the states have taken 100% of the stock but yet in states like Andhra, Telangana, Gujarat, Goa there has been distribution of 2-3 %’, BJP’s Vivek Reddy states, ‘Though the Central Government is a funder, the nodal agency for execution are the states. It is the states’ concern to identify the Migrants and reach out to them’.

WATCH!

snippet.title: Should social media giants like Facebook be more transparent? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, Sahar Zaman illustrates the Facebook row which is keenly been watched by a wide segment of people. The social media giant, Facebook seems to be facing a wrought of political rallies across the spectrum. The Central Government is accusing Facebook of being bullied by an anti-BJP bias.

Many political parties are raising questions over Facebook's neutrality, saying Facebook may influence upcoming elections. Should social media giants be more transparent? Is this really going to change things within Facebook, as it's used to the scrutiny?

Nikhil Pahwa, editor of Medianama says, ‘The pressure across political parties is rising against Facebook, and it needs to demonstrate that it has no bias. The platform has the power to shape our democracy. We've to hold it to a higher standard’.

While, Congress’ Rohan Gupta states, ‘In the last few days, there are 3 articles written by international media which exposes the nexus between Facebook India BJP. The senior officials of these platforms show their bias’, BJP’s Tuhin Sinha says, ‘BJP’s growth on social media right from the mid-2000s has been organic. Even if Facebook has had a bias, we’ve taken it in our stride & haven’t complained. We weren’t the ones who tried to hobnob with the Cambridge Analytica’

WATCH!

snippet.title: Is China provoking India into a military confrontation? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, Afrida Rahman Ali talks about some of the major issues buzzing around the nation and also illustrates the surging Indo-China border tension. According to the sources, Indian security forces today foiled an attempt by the Chinese Army to transgress into the Indian side of the LAC in the general area of Chumar.

Is China provoking India into a military confrontation?

‘We've to be eternally vigilant & ensure that they don't come in anymore from what they've already done’, says, Pinak Ranjan Chakravarty, Former Secretary, Ministry Of External Affairs. While, Strategic Affairs Expert & Consulting Editor of Times Network, Maroof Raza, says, ‘Our troops have shown that they're tougher than the Chinese troops. They can go out & face them head-on but, what's lacking is the political will’.

Meanwhile, Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has written a strongly worded letter to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg alleging bias towards the right-wing ideology.

The CBI team summoned prime accused in Sushant Singh Rajput’s Death Case, Rhea Chakraborty’s parents Indrajit and Sadhna Chakraborty. Along with them, Rhea and Sushant’s aides were also interrogated by the Central Agency.

The joint entrance exam for JEE aspirants was held today. Students were seen lining outside the examination centres with masks, gloves and sanitisers. The authorities also maintained strict vigilance to check if there is any violation.

WATCH!

snippet.title: Unlock 4.0 brings in new concerns; Is India now taking COVID-19 lightly? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, Sahar Zaman takes you through India’s COIVD-19 reality. Our country reported nearly 20 lakh Coronavirus cases in August and over 5 lakh cases recorded just in the last week of August. More than 75000 cases reported for five straight days between August 26 and 30.

As India unlocks, are there fresh fears? Is India now taking COVID-19 lightly?

Researcher, Global Health, Bioethics & Health Policy, Anant Bhan, says ‘Our absolute numbers are pretty alarming. This is not a time to loosen up. While it is important to focus on non-COVID healthcare, COVID-19 is a priority we should not be moving away from’; and, Nephron Clinics, Chairman, Dr Bagai says, ‘The herd immunity concept & the vaccine is a long way away. We should not bank on them. We shouldn’t be complacent or fall into mental fatigue’.  

Whereas, National Secretary of BJP RP Singh Khalsa says, ‘Gradually we have to bring the economy back & the society back to the system. We cannot keep sitting on lockdowns. We are well prepared’.

WATCH!

snippet.title: Should the loan moratorium scheme be extended amidst the COVID crisis? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate, as the six-month blanket Moratorium period to provide relief to borrowers ends today, demand for extension grows, should the Loan Moratorium scheme be extended any further? Avni Raja breaks down the entire concept for you.

If MSMEs are not taken care of by the government, it is going to have a huge blow to the economy. Loan Moratorium has to be extended by three months, says Founder and CEO of infiniX Venkatesh Pannirchelvan.

Former ED, RBI, and Economist Deepali Pant Joshi explain how there is not going to be a total remission, so one has to be ready to pay their installments, but banks also have to be ready to restructure loans, we all know that banks need to be well capitalised in order to keep lending.

snippet.title: JEE & NEET students remain clueless; What have states done to help the students? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate, JEE and NEET exams amidst the Coronavirus pandemic have not only created a huge uproar for the safety of students from the infection, but various parts of the country are facing heavy rainfall and flood-like situation, which have made life difficult for students. It is not easy for these students to commute to different areas and travel while risking their lives for an exam, still remains a huge debate.

Students from different parts of India explain the kind of problem they are facing, some are living in containment zones, while some are facing heavy rainfall. Shivansh Tyagi, a NEET aspirant from Muzaffarnagar, Uttar Pradesh explains how his exam centre is in Dehradun, which is 150 kilometres away from where he lives. Public transport is not available and the government is reiterating on the Standard Operating Measures. He further adds that a number of Ministers in the state have been infected with the virus despite the Standard Operating Measures. 

Tuhin A Sinha of BJP says, if NEET and JEE exams do not happen this year, the pressure will increase next year on the two batches competing, the number of seats will remain the same, but the competition will increase.

snippet.title: Nation salutes a Scholar & a Statesman: Former President Pranab Mukherjee | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate, Former President of India Pranab Mukherjee passed away at the age of 84 at the Army and Referral Hospital in New Delhi today, he died due to organ failures and had been fighting COVID-19 infection. His health had been fluctuating for the past few days and was admitted to the ICU ward. The entire country mourns his death and pays tribute to one of the best leaders India had. 

His son Abhijit Mukherjee took to Twitter to confirm the news of his death. Senior Congress leader Mani Shankar Aiyar stated that Pranab Mukherjee truly was a national leader rather than just a Congress leader because he had an incredibly warm rapport across the floor.

'Pranab Mukherjee was a wonderful human being, he always had pleasant words even for his opponents', says Former Governor,  Mizoram Amolak Rattan Kohl.

Senior Journalist Neerja Chowdhury says that India will remember Pranab Mukherjee as a man of consensus, consensus being the way to run India. She adds, his contributions were phenomenal and India will miss him.

snippet.title: Rhea Chakraborty's questioning by CBI underway; Will the truth prevail? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the chorus for justice for Sushant Singh Rajput has created a mass impact on the Indian audience, CBI, Enforcement Directorate and Narcotics Bureau are now investigating into a case that has not only gained mass momentum but also a huge uproar to punish the wrong people in Bollywood. 

Two things are critical, it is not just the quality of questions asked, but the inconsistencies in the statements given by suspects has inconsistencies from the backbone of what police may term as suspicion, says Mirror Now Managing Editor Vinay Tewari.

Mirror Now has accessed inside details of the line of investigation of the Narcotics Control Bureau. As per the statements by the sources, the Narcotics Control Bureau is not just focussing on drug angle in Sushant Singh Rajput's case but also aiming to expose the drug cartel network in Mumbai.

snippet.title: NEET & JEE amidst Coronavirus; Can states ask for college exam postponement? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the chorus for postponement of JEE and NEET exam continues and students raise their concerns over topics like health and transportation, the student-led movement has become a huge debate in the country amid the Coronavirus pandemic. 

Former ASG Bishwajit Bhattacharya says that if it is ensured by the centre and state in the true spirit of co-operative federalism that no student would face inconvenience or miss the exam, then NEET and JEE exams can be held. He further adds that we should not however be inflexible in our approach. 

Senior Supreme Court advocate Geeta Luthra says that if the Supreme Court acknowledges that there are certain powers with the states under the Disaster Management Act for final year exams, can that also be used for JEE and NEET students, even though these are National level exams. 

Congress' Nasir Hussain states that these are the times when the government has to show empathy to the students. The government has failed to make use of these three-four months. It is not the duty of the opposition parties to arrange for logistical support.

snippet.title: CBI, ED & Narcotics Bureau investigate Sushant Singh Rajput's case | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the narcotics bureau has now come into the picture, what is that the Enforcement Directorate has told them?

Enforcement Directorate officials and Rhea Chakraborty's father Indrajit Chakraborty left the bank after six hours. Indrajit Chakraborty's lockers were searched by the Enforcement Directorate. Rhea Chakraborty's father has been taken to the Axis Bank branch in Vakola, Mumbai.

New drug angle that has now come into the picture with Gaurav Arya as the main drug dealer in the case, Narcotics bureau has sent a team to Goa to further investigate into the case.

Managing Editor at Mirror Now Vinay Tewari says that this is a deliberate strategy employed by investigating agencies in cases that do not have obvious evidence of a crime having being committed.

snippet.title: Neelkantha Bhanu Prakash: The man who broke Shakuntala Devi's record | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Fastest Human Calculator Neelkantha Bhanu Prakash shares his journey and how he has been preparing himself. He says that he is able to calculate at the speed of 12 numbers per second and this is judged by looking into addition, subtraction, division, multiplication, and analyzing how many calculations he does per second.

He also talks about when the definition of math education changes, everyone can have an experience like his and excel in it, he also adds that people are extremely scared because math is promoted as a science and not an art form.

Neelkantha Bhanu Prakash also explains how the bigger cause of his small achievement, is to make this brain training a popular culture and to make people understand the math is an enabler.

snippet.title: JEE and NEET exams amidst high COVID cases; Small towns & rural India forgotten? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, while several opposition ruled states continue to demand that exams should be postponed, the centre remains firm on its stand to conduct exams. Education Minister says students want exams to be held at any cost. Ritik Jain, a JEE aspirant says that he lives in a containment zone and there are limited transport options available for him which will make it difficult for him to travel to the exam centre.

'My exam centre is in Patna, atleast 220 kilometres from where I live', says Dhiraj Kumar, a JEE aspirant from Paschim Champaran, Bihar, he further adds that even if he finds a way to travel, his parents will travel with him.

Somesh Laheri, another JEE aspirant from Purulia, West Bengal says that he has to rent a private vehicle to travel to the exam centre, which is about 100 kilometres away, he further adds that he has two exams, so he will have to spend Rs 15,000, as there are not many options.

snippet.title: Loan relief for borrowers; Should the interest during a moratorium be charged? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the demand for loan relief extension grows, should the interest during a moratorium be charged? Tanvi Shukla questions if the moratorium on term loans be extended?

Sanjay Shah, MD at Vinis Products Pvt Ltd explains how many things were announced today, but in reality, a lot more needs to be done. BJP's Gopal K Agarwal says that there is a need to help businesses, he further questions about retailer borrowers, those who have lost their jobs, those who have had to shut businesses, have had to struggle to pay employees or run their own families, he questions the relief provided to them.

Joel Rebello, Assistant Editor at The Economic Times, explains that the Reserve Bank of India has one or two options right now, he further explains that the first option is that they will give borrowers more time to pay or probably reduce the rates for now and elongate the tenure.

snippet.title: How will JEE and NEET exams be held amidst the rise in COVID cases? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the NEET and JEE aspirants versus the state authorities have been at war over the examination row amidst the Coronavirus pandemic, the students will highlight their problems as to why examination amidst the pandemic is a challenge and the problem that the organizing authorities, National Testing Agency, Education Ministry of India and the Central government do not seem to understand.

Sanat Alok, who is a NEET aspirant from Bihar explains how the centre in Patna is 450 kilometres away from his residence, he adds that his village is flooded which has made commuting to different areas very difficult. He questions the central government, as not everybody is privileged enough to have personal vehicles, it is wrong for underprivileged people to risk their lives and go for the test.

Tapajeet Roy, another NEET aspirant from Assam, explains how the electricity is a major problem in his city and it usually comes for two hours, it is not only easy for him to study but the disastrous floods and no proper transportation have made it difficult for him to reach the exam centre that is in Guwahati which is 160 kilometres away from his place.

Krishna Singh, an aspirant from Begusarai, Bihar, questions the central government as there are no proper measures taken in Bihar pertaining to the ongoing heavy rainfall and floods in the state, it has not only made life difficult for the people but traveling is yet another issue faced by many. He further adds that private vehicles usually charge around Rs 8,000-10,000 which is very expensive considering the pandemic and financial loss that people have been facing.

snippet.title: Unlock Stage 4: Is it time for pan-India to allow interdistrict travel? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as Karnataka leads in easing lockdown norms, the question as to how will the other states follow the COVID guidelines, still remains a question. With the rising COVID cases, is India ready to unlock the remaining services?

Vivek S Reddy of BJP explains how the Karnataka government has looked at the emerging COVID situation and has planned accordingly, ensuring that there is a balance between COVID preparedness, COVID caution, and opening up the economy. Clyde Crasto, NCP says that when it comes to opening up Maharashtra, it has to be done slowly and carefully. He further adds that there are good signs which prove that things are looking better.

Kovai Sathyan, AIADMK, says that if the inter-state travel is opened, there has to be a common mechanism followed where the data can be spooled at one common centre and can be shared with all the other states.

snippet.title: JEE & NEET exams amidst rising pandemic, Can states ensure COVID protocols? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as India is battling the COVID pandemic, students are preparing themselves for JEE and NEET exams, amidst the Coronavirus era, it has made life difficult for everybody including students. Are students risking their lives or future, still remains a question. 

Bharat Uday, a JEE aspirant speaks to Tanvi Shukla about how important it is to conduct the exams right now because students have been preparing for these exams for two-three years. He further adds that putting students under pressure by not conducting the exams is not good for their mental health. He explains how difficult it is to prepare for these exams and students cannot afford to lose touch with their studies. 

Kalikesh Narayan Singh Deo, Former member of the parliament Lok Sabha, BJD explains how tens of thousands of students will be packed in one little room, he says that the government of India has not thought this through. He adds that the answer is certainly not to have the exams in today's circumstances. 

Nasir Hussain, Congress too believes that the Supreme Court itself was shut and cases are being heard virtually, while the court itself is not in a position to meet regularly and hear the cases, they want one generation of students to risk their lives. Advait, a NEET aspirant, believes that exams should not be held in this uncertain situation, no standard operating measure can ensure the safety of the students.

snippet.title: 1.89 crore salaried jobs lost; What can India do to create more jobs? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, a report from the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy shows that nearly 19 million salaried people lost their jobs between April and July, Tanvi Shukla breaks down the data in order to help understand the scenario. 'The distress is felt in most of the sectors even today' says Aditya N Mishra who is the CEO at Ciel H R India, he further adds that there are only a few sub-sectors where there is some activity. 

R Sriram, Resident Editor, The Economic Times explains that the next four-six months are crucial, it is very difficult to say how things will pan out, but it all depends on the possibility on the lockdown, economic growth, the possibility of a vaccine, government measures and the sentiment carried forward by the people. 

Professor Santosh Mehrotra highlights that there is plenty of evidence to show that we should not be expecting the salaried jobs to be coming back for a fair bit of time.

snippet.title: Congress Drama Ends: Can Congress ever move beyond the Gandhi narrative? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the chorus for a 'non-Gandhi leader' had taken a huge political turn in the Congress party, Madhavan Narayan, a senior journalist, says that for the first time in 25 years, we are seeing something that looks like dissent on a significant scale. The dissent remains a bigger news item than resolution in Congress party.

Radhika Rameseshan, Consulting Editor at Business Standard explains how today's events indicate that the Gandhis alone has the prerogative to lay out a roadmap for their party, she further adds that anyone else who dares to make some proposal, will not be taken kindly. 

SP Ghanshyam Tiwari explains how the political turn of events was a bad PR for the Congress party, he further explains how this will open doors for issues and leaders that are important to the country to come at a National Stage and find a spotlight for themselves.

snippet.title: How are Ganpati celebrations being witnessed at the famous Lalbaugcha Raja? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvu Shukla, the number of COVID cases in the country is peaking and the pandemic is clashing with the festival season. Series of festivals are now beginning in the country, across states and will go on for several months. 2020 the year of Coronavirus pandemic has stopped the festivities but people are celebrating it in their houses. Is it safe to allow festivities now, still remains a big question? 

Ganesh Chaturthi which is all set to take place on August 22. The festival is supposed to be observed across the country and the other perspective is that should the celebration of the festivals be made a private affair? One is allowed to do whatever they want to do, they can follow the traditions, customs and figure out a unique way of worshipping inside your own house.

snippet.title: EC issues new COVID norms to conduct Bihar polls; Is it a free and fair choice? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, now that the Election Commission has released new COVID guidelines and Standard Operating Measures to conduct Bihar elections amidst the COVID pandemic, the new guidelines present special voting rules for COVID-19 patients. Tanvi Shukla takes you through the key highlights and the challenges for the Bihar polls.

Manoj Kumar Jha, MP from RJP questions that the party has been very skeptical about holding elections amid a pandemic, he questions the take on the guidelines that have been issued by the Election Commission for Bihar Elections. 

Ayishwarya M, Spokesperson from Congress says 'Why does Congress party believe that this will not lead to free and fair elections?' Shailesh Gandhi, Former CICI says that looking at what the Election Commission is proposing, he thinks that they have made a fairly decent effort to meet various issues that may come up. He further adds that there might be other issues but for that Election Commission must sit and discuss and people should cooperate.

snippet.title: Low-key Ganesh Chaturthi preparations; Is it safe to allow festivities now? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as India is all set to celebrate Ganesh Chaturthi amidst the COVID pandemic, the question if India is safe to allow festivities still remains intact. Will India's discipline be tested in the festive period? or should the celebration of festivals be a private affair?

Many Indian states have released their Standard Operating Measures so people follow the COVID guidelines and the spread of the virus is curbed. For the first time in 87 years, Mumbai's famous Lalbaughcha Raja will not witness grand festivities during Ganesh Chaturthi, instead, there will be a plasma and blood donation camp, Balasaheb Kamble, who is the President at Lalbaugcha Raja Committee speaks to Tanvi Shukla.

Rahul Eshwar, who is a social activist, explains how we need to have a sensitive striking balance between celebrating festivals, opening up the economy, and having health concerns. Rahul further adds that caution is the only way ahead, even as a practicing believer, listening to doctors and scientists is important.

snippet.title: Prashant Bhushan's critic tweet on the judiciary, What constitutes contempt? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate, We put the spotlight on one of the big controversies that have got everybody talking from the political circles to the legal circles, retired Supreme Court judges and top lawyers of our country are talking about it. This pertains to a case that is going on in the Supreme Court right now. A case of contempt proceedings or criminal contempt proceedings against Prashant Bhushan who is a noted lawyer.

The Supreme Court has already found him guilty of contempt because of two tweets that he put out. These tweets were regarding the Supreme Court. One specifically about the Chief Justice of India and the other one about the Supreme Court and former Chief Justices of India.

In light of this, the Supreme Court has found Prashant Bhushan guilty of contempt but they yet to decide on what his punishment should be? 

The Supreme Court did ask Prashant Bhushan if he wanted to reconsider his statements, withdraw them or apologise for them. But Prashant Bhushan said no and he said he believes in what he said.

snippet.title: Row over Facebook post; Supreme Court on Sushant Singh Rajput's case | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, Tanvi Shukla takes you through two such stories that have evoked major controversies, political row, debates and a lot more in the last few weeks. 

1) In Facebook favours BJP row, the Congress party has now written a letter to the social media giant ‘Facebook’ CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, seeking a high-level inquiry into the top leadership of Facebook India. They also said that the report should be submitted within two months. Now who should stop the hate comment, Facebook or the Central Government?

2) The Supreme Court will soon pronounce its verdict on the most-talked death case of Late Sushant Singh Rajput. While the nation is pleading for a CBI investigation, many pujas, campaigns and movements are been taken place across the globe, only to seek justice for Sushant.

So who will investigate Sushant’s case? Will Rhea’s plea to transfer the case be approved by the Apex? Will take be a CBI probe? Will justice prevail to Sushant Singh Rajput? Too many questions will be finally answered by the Supreme Court.

snippet.title: CBI verdict by Supreme Court; A big blow for Uddhav government? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as India celebrates the historic judgment by the Supreme Court that ruled a CBI probe in Sushant Singh Rajput's death case, how has Maharashtra been responding to the entire narrative was being discussed. 

The BJP and their allies have not forgotten how they were kept away from government formation in Maharashtra. To destabilise Uddhav Thackeray is one of the main projects of this exercise. This is a clearcut of the political vendetta being followed, says, senior journalist Ashutosh.

Managing Editor of Mirror Now Mr. Vinay Tewari says that there is no party better than BJP to understand the importance of strategically calculating how to utilise an opportunity, in this case, the Maharashtra government provided the opportunity on a platter. The Maharashtra government and Mumbai police were slow to respond to the public pressure for a fair investigation. If they had been more prompt, the verdict would have been different, says senior journalist Anay Joglekar.

Former DGP of Bihar SK Bhardwaj says that the Mumbai police obstructed the probe from the very beginning, they should have made the postmortem and inquest report public. He further adds that the case must go to an independent agency like CBI.

#SCBacksCBIForSSR #SushantSinghRajputDeathCase

snippet.title: SC's decision on CBI probe; 5 reasons why Maharashtra govt got the case wrong | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the Supreme Court has laid their decision on the CBI probe, millions in the country are celebrating the historic movement that was started via social media for Sushant Singh Rajput's death case. Tanvi Shukla takes you through five reasons why the Maharashtra government got the case wrong. 

The Supreme Court mentioned in the verdict that they found no wrongdoing in the inquiry by Mumbai police. The CBI should now be given a chance to investigate in a proper and quiet manner without cacophony and controversies, says MN Singh who is a former Commissioner of Police, Mumbai.

Senior Advocate at Supreme Court, Geeta Luthra says that Maharashtra police's conclusion in an inquest has to be much quicker. She also adds that they perhaps could be faulted for being too slow, but they were doing a thorough investigation.

#SCBacksCBIForSSR #SushantSinghRajputDeathCase
