snippet.title: Bengaluru COVID cases increase with a shortage in healthcare staff? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Why did the Bengaluru COVID model fail?

From 386 cases as of June 1 to 9580 cases as of July 5, Bengaluru sees a massive jump in the number of COVID cases. 
BJP leader Dr. Narendra Rangappa says "We have not let our guard down. There are many factors responsible for the increase in the number of cases. The growth rate is well under control." 

Whereas, the Public Health Expert Dr. Sylvia Karpagam says “Patients who could've been kept in primary or secondary level facilities & those who are asymptomatic are occupying beds which should be reserved for serious patients. There is a lack of planning.” 

Kerala Gold Smuggling Case:
Kerala CM distances his govt from smuggling scandal after Principal Secretary was sacked for his alleged link to accused Swapna Suresh. 30kg of gold, brought in a diplomatic bag addressed to the UAE consulate was seized at Thiruvananthapuram airport. 
The News Minute’s Sreedevi Jay shares the details of the Kerala Gold Smuggling Case. 

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Is COVID vaccine stiff deadline scientifically unrealistic? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the COVID Vaccine Controversy 

ICMR sets the August 15 deadline for the vaccine. Experts say vaccine by August not feasible Is a stiff deadline scientifically unrealistic? Is setting a deadline in the development stage dangerous? What are the pitfalls in rushing through a vaccine? 

National Centre for Biological Sciences Prof. Sudhir Krishna says "You have to give ICMR the benefit of the doubt. They are trying to push this process at a very complex time. One should look at the larger vaccine ecosystem.''

Prof Rajib Dasgupta explains the various stages involved in developing a vaccine. 

EpidemioloFastrack Tanmay Mahapatra answers "How do we fastrack a vaccine development program without compromising on the health & safety part?"

 Dr. David Nabarro WHO's Special Envoy on COVID 19 says "The spread is via droplets which do not travel more than about a meter or so. We need to think of the commonest modes of transmission, & our thinking is still that droplet spread is the commonest mode. It is really important that people practice all precautions together. Always wear a mask and maintain physical distance." He further adds "I'd like people not to think in terms of having a vaccine that is ready for everybody in less than 'two or two & a half years."

When Dr. Ram Vishwakarma from the Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine was asked Is Coronavirus Airborne? He said "I don't think there is anything alarmist about it. This gives more importance to wearing masks. People should simply be more responsible."

localized.title: Is COVID vaccine stiff deadline scientifically unrealistic? | The Urban Debate
localized.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the COVID Vaccine Controversy 

ICMR sets the August 15 deadline for the vaccine. Experts say vaccine by August not feasible Is a stiff deadline scientifically unrealistic? Is setting a deadline in the development stage dangerous? What are the pitfalls in rushing through a vaccine? 

National Centre for Biological Sciences Prof. Sudhir Krishna says "You have to give ICMR the benefit of the doubt. They are trying to push this process at a very complex time. One should look at the larger vaccine ecosystem.''

Prof Rajib Dasgupta explains the various stages involved in developing a vaccine. 

EpidemioloFastrack Tanmay Mahapatra answers "How do we fastrack a vaccine development program without compromising on the health & safety part?"

 Dr. David Nabarro WHO's Special Envoy on COVID 19 says "The spread is via droplets which do not travel more than about a meter or so. We need to think of the commonest modes of transmission, & our thinking is still that droplet spread is the commonest mode. It is really important that people practice all precautions together. Always wear a mask and maintain physical distance." He further adds "I'd like people not to think in terms of having a vaccine that is ready for everybody in less than 'two or two & a half years."

When Dr. Ram Vishwakarma from the Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine was asked Is Coronavirus Airborne? He said "I don't think there is anything alarmist about it. This gives more importance to wearing masks. People should simply be more responsible."

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Who is shielding gangster Vikas Dubey? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, its been 3 days since Vikas Dubey & gang massacred 8 cops. 

Despite that, U.P. police has no breakthrough or clue. Investigations have revealed that there was a mole in the police department who tipped off Dubey 4 hours before the raid. 

Who is shielding gangster Vikas Dubey? 

Journalist Piyush Rai says "The autopsy reports of DSP Devendra Mishra had signs of ‘Revenge Killing’. It never looked like it was an encounter. Vikas Dubey sent out the message that he wasn’t just prepared but also well protected."

However, Former Commissioner of Police TR Kakkar says "This definitely is a blot on the efficient functioning of the UP Police  and the sooner they correct it the better it will be."

Manish Shukla from BJP says “The way #VikasDubey used to openly talk about his reach, does this not prove that he had political and police contacts?”

Whereas, Ghanshyam Tiwari from Samajwadi Party says  "Despite 150 cases linked to Vikas Dubey, he is not named as one of the Top 10 criminals in his district. His name will not be found in any major file of the Uttar Pradesh Govt. He was supported end-to-end by the BJP establishment."

Former DGP of UP M. C. Dwivedi says "The way Vikas Dubey has risen in the crime world is very fast, and sufficient action has not been taken by any Govt so far."
 
Journalist Piyush Rai says "Criminals like Vikas Dubey have cordial relations with the police. Cordial cuts both ways, the gangster would be obliging the department and the department would be repaying the favor in some or the other way."

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Will India lead the race for COVID-19 vaccine? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the ongoing debate for the COVID-19 cure that has been a current topic of discussion for various medical health officials was discussed. Tanvi Shukla questions Dr. Rakesh Mishra, Director at Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology on how long does it take for a vaccine to be ready and safe to be used. 

Dr. Anant Bhan, Researcher, Global Heath at Bioethics and Health Policy explains why the timeline of getting a vaccine by mid-August is bizarre.

Tanvi Shukla also questions Dr. Ramanan Laxminarayan, Affiliate Professor, University of Washington, on how far is the world in the various projects that we have, from finding a vaccine for COVID-19. 

Abantika Ghosh, the Senior Associate Editor at The Print, says there exists a lot of confusion. The clinical trial registry data, that she read says Phase 2 of the trial is supposed to examine the immunogenicity of the vaccine till day 194, which itself is more than 6 months.

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Uttar Pradesh: Are mafias thriving in the gang culture? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the Kanpur Encounter which witnessed the death of 8 policemen, including a DSP, were killed by a gangster named Vikas Dubey. Tanvi Shukla and Vinay Tewari, Mirror Now's Managing Editor explain who he was and how the encounter unfolded in Uttar Pradesh. 

There have been various operations to clean up the mafia during many Chief Ministers' regimes. The mafia survives because it has deep links inside villages. Police infrastructure is not upgraded on the task-oriented basis, says Yasho Azad, Former IPS officer. 

These kinds of criminals always thrive, whatever the regime be because they conveniently stick to loyalties to the parties in power. This is why at the current moment, Vikas Dubey was closely affiliated to the ruling party in Uttar Pradesh, that is the BJP, says Sharat Pradhan, Senior Journalist. 

Watch!

snippet.title: Are Indian politicians making a mockery out of lockdown guidelines? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, after Prime Minister Narendra Modi made a speech on how Unlock 1.0 had noticed violators who broke the lockdown rules and guidelines, did not wear proper face masks and did not manage any social distancing. Another such incident uprising from the Politicians has been into talks. The VVIP violators who are supposed to 'guard' the nation from the pandemic with strong policies and adequate governance are now violating these guidelines. 

Ravi Chandra Reddy, of YSRCP, asks what actions have been taken against the leaders who have risked their own lives as well as those present while violating the social distancing norms.

Mr. DM Shivakumar has been a classic example of a violation of COVID-19 norms. He did not follow any rule that was mentioned in the COVID-19 pamphlet. Common people are being fined for flouting norms in Karnataka.

Tanvi Shukla also reads out the incidents from different states where there have been cases of VVIP violation, she also asks Gopal K Agarwal of BJP, on how many politicians have been booked for violating lockdown norms.

Manu Aiyappa, Chief of Political Bureau, The Times of India in Bengaluru, says it is not about the party, the political across party believe that they are totally immune to COVID-19. Despite the data that shows almost 50 politicians have fallen ill and there have been a couple of deaths due to the virus too.
Watch!

snippet.title: Are Indian hospitals under pressure to hide COVID-19 deaths? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as COVID-19 cases in India are spiking a new number on a daily basis, so are the number of death cases. India has witnessed more than 17,000 deaths but somehow death cases are kept hidden.

Mahesh Tapase, NCP talks about how data on COVID deaths under no circumstances should be hidden or fudged. If it is a COVID death, it should be pronounced as one.

Dr. Abhay Shukla, National Co-convener at Jan Swasthya Abhiyan explains how the death audit that was conducted in Maharashtra, on the Coronavirus cases in Mumbai, shows 79 percent of cases had co-morbidities. ICMR also mentioned that COVID-19 must be mentioned as a cause of death even if it is an underlying cause. 

Dr. Mahesh Chandra Misra, Former Director, AIIMS also mentioned how there exists a discrepancy in the number of COVID-19 cases and it is said to remain. India has witnessed more than 6 lakh cases that have tested positive currently, but there are maybe 4 times this number as many have not been tested so far and there exists a possibility that they will never be tested.

Watch the video to know!

snippet.title: Doctors who led the fight against COVID-19 in worst hit cities | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as India commemorates the frontline warriors of COVID-19 pandemic, the entire nation celebrated the spirit of doctors by wishing them a Happy Doctor's Day.

Mirror Now speaks to the leading doctor to know about the many battles being fought against COVID-19 pandemic across the country. 

Dr. Sudarshan Ballal, Chairman at Manipal Hospitals, talks about how doctors are meant to take care of people who are unwell, but at the same time, it is necessary that healthcare workers remain healthy too, otherwise the healthcare system would collapse. 

There were a few doctors who got infected with COVID-19 while treating other COVID-19 patients and had to undergo quarantine measures, says, Dr. Rahul Pandit of Fortis Hospital.

Dr. Randeep Guleria, Director at AIIMS, also talks about how life for doctors has changed dramatically since the COVID-19 pandemic has struck the global scenario. Doctors now spend days looking at patients, planning how to work on increasing patient load and protecting healthcare workers, which in fact in a situation like is very challenging. 

Watch!

snippet.title: Ramdev's Ayurveda treatment: Modern medicines biased against traditional cure? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Patanjali claiming to launch COVID-19 medicine was discussed. The debate over the COVID drug is now taking the Ayurveda versus Allopathy turn, where Ramdev expressed his concern over the bias and prejudice against Ayurveda. 

The ongoing question pertaining to modern medicine being biased towards a traditional cure is being talked about. 

Dr. Sukumar Sadeshmukh of Ayurvedgram says that there exists defamation towards Ayurveda from the modern fraternity. When a patient comes to an Ayurvedic doctor and suggests to take a COVID test, he is not allowed to.

There is no cure for COVID-19 in any 'pathy'. Since, Ayurveda is considered apathy with well-known remedies which intern help in boosting the immune, says, Dr. Asmita Wele, Professor at College of Ayurved, Bhartiya Vidyapeeth.

Dr. Sumaiya Shaikh, a Neuroscientist, explains how Ayurveda has gone back and forth between immunity-boosting and the ongoing COVID-19 treatment. She also mentions how there exists nothing that can boost your immunity in an innate way through herbal cure.
Watch!

snippet.title: Chinese mobile applications' privacy concerns a threat to India's sovereignty? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the massive move by the Indian government to delist Chinese mobile applications citing privacy and security concerns were discussed. As India is taking the Galwan gallantry to a new level by dismantling the Chinese economy. 

Dr. Pavan Duggal, Cyberlaw expert says the ban on Chinese mobile applications should be a wake-up call for a large number of Indian users who are consuming the application. Some users do not bother to read the privacy policies and tend to mindlessly accept all the permissions that are sought by the application. 

Tarun Wig, Information Security Consultant, talks about how documents that are scanned using CamScanner, another popular mobile application, have been stored on Chinese servers. UCBrowser has also stored the content that people have searched for on the internet. He explains how people download the mobile application and the settings are automatically changed to ensure all the data goes to them.

Tarun Wig, then explains how certain mobile applications require permission to access, and if one feels to restrict, they can deny the permission too.

Watch!

snippet.title: PM Modi's 'Free-Ration' move, A solution to migrant crisis or a political agenda? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed the nation on the Unlock 2.0 rules and regulations and what has been teh status of the country while fighting the global pandemic. Prime Minister also provided details of the progress report of the welfare schemes. 

Javed Ansari, Senior Journalist says, Prime Minister has an eye on the upcoming Bihar polls, he says this move tried to take away some light from the damage that was caused by the chaotic mismanagement and how the goverment handled the migrant crisis. He says there was a larger political intent that was announced today.

The Garib Kalyan Yojana, that was introduced for the migrant laborers, is a welcoming move to the migrant crisis. There have been larger number of migrants that were impacted in the nation wide lockdown, says Vinay Tewari, Managing Editor at Mirror Now. He also says the scheme should have been announced for a longer duration earlier. 

Yogendra Yadav of Swaraj India explains how 80 crore people have been getting ration for over 10 years, under the National Food Security Act. The goverment has now subsidized the rates.

snippet.title: Chinese applications banned in India, was privacy and security at stake? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, as the Indian government has embarked on an unprecedented move, by attacking the Chinese economy and dismantling it from the very bottom. Right after the Galwan clashes, the Indian government lost 20 soldiers and the state is now leading a charge against the Chinese Communist Party. India has punished China's betrayal in the Galwan clashes by delisting Chinese mobile applications. It is reported that India has banned around 59 mobile applications and has removed it too. It is said that these mobile applications will no longer be legal in this country.

Cyber Security expert Rishesh says, everyone in the industry has been aware of snooping and spying and citizens should understand the concept of privacy as it is way more important than anything else.

snippet.title: Does police brutality have a price to pay? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the ongoing case of police brutality was discussed, shedding light on how important it is for us to acknowledge that exists in our society. The brutal death of Jayaraj and Benicks talks about police brutality and custodial deaths in India. There needs to a safer space if the ones who are supposed to guard the people, take law in their hands.
Priyanka Thirumurthy of TheNewsMinute highlights instances wherein these police officials have been involved in other cases of police brutality. 

Times Network's Ahmad Shabbir spoke to one of the cops who is linked to the Thoothukudi Custodial Death case about how Jayaraj and Benicks got injuries. The cop initially denied saying there were no injuries but after further questioning, he told a different version of the story.

"No Police Officer will willingly kill someone", says M R Nandakumar, Former Additional SP of Chennai.

As the Judicial Magistrate told Madras High Court that police are not cooperating. If the police have not done anything intentionally, then the fact that they are not cooperating with the judiciary is questionable. Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Will investing in plasma therapy hold promise to battle COVID-19 out? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Delhi has noticed a huge spike in COVID-19 cases. Not only has the states created enough measures with an adequate health structure, but it has also increased the testing rate as well. Now that Delhi's Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal has introduced the Plasma bank in the state, which is considered as India's first plasma bank.
It is noticed that various states in India are now investing a lot more in Plasma Therapy to battle Coronavirus. Dr. Jayanti Shastri, of Nair Hospital, and Dr. Rakesh Mishra, Director of Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology explains the importance of plasma therapy. They also talk about how effective it is in a country like ours, and what challenges can we face as a society.

snippet.title: Will Congress respond to the allegations of diverting public funds in PMNRF? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out details of the corruption scandal that has rocked the nation from the time the UPA government was in power with the Congress as the head. Shocking donations were made from the PM National Relief Fund and several government ministries to the Rajiv Gandhi Foundation. 

For a party that has been asking for transparency from the Centre on the spending of the PM Cares Fund established to fight COVID, there is a lot to answer for. 

"Money was diverted for personal use&this needs to be investigated. It's not that we're saying something that we can't prove,” says, Dr Syed Zafar, BJP Spokesperson 

The Congress has responded to the allegations of corruption being levelled against it, rubbishing the claims. 

"Is it not bizarre that BJP govt is giving donations & funds to RSS & BJP affiliate. By that logic isn't that dubious? This is how NGOs are funded,” says, Supriya Shrinate, Congress Spokesperson 

As the India-China conflict shows no clear sign of de-escalation can India depend on the assistance of the US to tackle China diplomatically? 

U.S. Secretary of Department of State says that the U.S will ensure that it's postured appropriately to counter the Chinese Army.

What are the next possible steps for India? 

#CongressReliefFundLoot #IndiaChinaConflict

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Thoothukudi custodial death case no arrests yet, Why has there been no action? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out the shocking and horrific details of the Thoothukudi Custodial Death case, where extreme police brutality led to the death of Jayaraj and his son Fenix. The incident has sparked outrage as people take to the streets to demand justice, yet there have been no arrests. 

"The police do not apply their brains when they file any other sort of FIR. They file an FIR for everything under the sun. But when it comes to filing an FIR against their own people, then they are suddenly reminded about legal procedures?" Asks, Dhanya Rajendran, Editor, The News Minute

The question is who is taking accountability for the deaths, as the devastated family demands answers from the government and courts.

 "All the good work done by the Tamil Nadu police has been brought to nought by this single episode, this ghastly incident," says, Vikram Singh, Former DGP, U.P

The painful and unfortunate incident has brought to the forefront the harsh reality of police brutality, will this be the wake-up call for the authorities? 

#ThoothukudiPoliceBrutality 

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Are cosmetic changes like rebranding enough to tackle racism & prejudice? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out if the decision of Hindustan Unilever to rebrand its popular cream, ‘Fair & lovely’ is a genuine step in the right direction to tackle racism or is it just another gimmick? 

"This brand has become a household name today. What about 45 years of damage & the wrong messaging about women's empowerment? There should we more than just changing the name" says, Kavitha Emmanuel, Founder of 'Dark is Beautiful' Campaign

The question remains that will this change which has caused a raging debate across the country spark a larger fire that addresses this problem in other spheres like advertising and Bollywood. 

"Problem is not the sale but the propaganda", says Manoj Muntashir, Lyricist & Screenwriter

People across the world today are campaigning to mark the beauty of all persons irrespective of skin tones, is India maturing with the times? 

#FairAndLovely

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: How should India tackle the education crisis caused by COVID-19 pandemic? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out if the decision of the CBSE and ICSE boards to cancel exams amid COVID case surge is in favour of the students. Uncertainty surrounds the student community as they wonder if the schedule for competitive exams for higher students will also be changed. 

There has also been significant reservation on the decision to evaluate and promote students based on previous scores and internal assessment.

“If we plan to go by the internal assessment, our internal assessment are not that good, we tend to work harder for the boards,” says, Arya Sethi, 12th Grade CBSE Student 

There has been widespread questioning on CBSE offering give ‘exams later’ to students as an option. 

“I think leaving the entire internal assessment as the basis of admission for colleges, opens a whole new set of problems. What is the sanctity of the scores that’ll get submitted?” Says, Aakash Chaudhry, Director and CEO, Aakash Educational Services Limited 

The decision to cancel exams has been long drawn and full of ambiguities which add to the pain of both students as well as worried parents. 

#BoardExamMess 

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: What should Maharashtra do to curb the pandemic? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out what are pain points in Maharashtra as it continues to remain the worst affected state in the country by the COVID-19 pandemic. What is causing this unrelenting grip of the crisis and who is responsible for the current situation in Mumbai? 

“Antigen based tests which will be launched soon can be done in larger numbers. We need to do more tests,” says, Dr Laxman Jessani, Consultant, Apollo Hospitals

Mumbai has recorded miserably low testing rates, which according to experts is one of the central reasons for the city’s crisis as asymptotic infected persons pose a grave threat. 

The opposition has lashed out at the ruling party led by Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray asking what direction is the state heading towards a healthcare disaster. 

“There's a huge disparity between the percentage of cases in Maharashtra contributes & the % of death, & this disparity could only be because there's large % of unreported cases,” says, Tuhin Sinha, BJP Spokesperson 

How will Maharashtra cope with the challenges that it’s facing in Mumbai as well as other satellite towns? 

#MaharashtraCOVIDCrisis

snippet.title: Fuel prices continue to rise, Will aam aadmi get respite? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out how the decision of the government to hike fuel prices 18-days in a row affects the Aam Aadmi buried under the pressures of a pandemic. Is there a middle ground where the government  earns but the common man doesn’t bear the full burden? 

“What are the other ways of raising funds of taxation than this method?” explains, Saurabh Chandra, Former Secretary, Petroleum Ministry

The opposition has questioned the Centre’s asking about the funds it has collected during its term and how it plans to continue this hike if people are unhappy. 

“We should get Petrol & Diesel under VAT. Over 120 lakh crore money that GOI had collected in last 6-years by increasing prices of fuel, where's that money being used, if that's not being utilised during an emergency?” Says, Radhika Khera, Congress Spokesperson 

There has been a call to action in India as the debate rages on however, the central issue remains the need to find a better solution that serves as a compromise between the people and the administration. 

#FuelPricesHiked



Watch!

snippet.title: Is it safe for states to hold exams amid a pandemic or should they be cancelled? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out if the decision to conduct board exams by states like Karnataka will hurt the students in the middle of a pandemic. The cases of COVID-19 are surging across the country bringing up the question, can the government ensure that the safety of the students will not be compromised? 

“We do understand the government has done a lot to get this going, but I don't think anybody in this world can right now guarantee 100% safety,” says Srinivas, President, Managements of Independent CBSE School Association

Parents across the nation have expressed concern and anxiety as they grapple with the twin fear of Coronavirus pandemic and the future of their children. Who will bear the onus of this dilemma and is the country prepared to deal with the crisis. 

“The environment is anxious at home. The examination has taken up a different outlook altogether. It is not an exam, it’s like they're going for a war,” says, Kajal Roy, Parent

Board exams in India have always been high-pressure situations that have given students and parents sleepless nights but is this double dilemma of a pandemic going to be the breaking point? 

#BoardExamsSuspense 

Watch to know more!

snippet.title: What are the key challenges as India and China try to map out the way ahead? I The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, find out the status of the India-China standoff as the nation attempts to strategise all fronts including military, economic and political. There are several challenges standing in the way of bilateral relations between the two nations normalising after the violent Galwan Valley clash. 

"One will have to keep in mind that this disengagement will take, over a period of time and not suddenly,” says Snehesh Philip, Senior Associate Editor, The Print 

The Chinese aggression at the border and the Indian response in retaliation especially after 20 soldiers of the Indian armed forces were martyred. There has been fervour and call to action in the country for the economic boycott of Chinese companies by all people. 

“You're dealing with a very deceptive advisory. Whenever China feels that international laws are in their favour, they will cite those to you, but whenever it's not, they'll use force,” says, Manu Pubby, Senior Editor, Economic Times 

The government has decided to allow the Puri Jagannath Rath Yatra after the nod from the Supreme Court leading to massive debate in the country on whether prayer can be prioritised over pandemic. 

“How can we ensure that even in times of Pandemic, people can hold basic rituals but don't resort to the usual kind of festivities?” Says, AL Banerjee, Former Top Cop

Will the government be able to fulfil its promise and ensure its precautions meet up to the massive challenge awaiting it amid COVID-19 case surge?



 #IndiaChinaWayAhead

#JagannathRathYatraAllowed

snippet.title: Cases of COVID-19 surge in cities across India, who is to blame for this lapse? I The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the big question is what has caused the rampant violation of the lockdown norms in the cities? Metro cities across India are today COVID-19 hotspots because of this ‘take it easy’ approach. Find out who is to blame for this lapse, which endangers the safety of the people and threatens the healthcare sector. 



“It's the responsibility of individual & society to make sure that it doesn't come to a situation that you lose everything that you have gained, in last 8-10 weeks of lockdown,” says, Dr Om Srivastav, Director, Infectious diseases, Jaslok Hospital and Research Centre



Despite several areas and districts being declared containment zones in Delhi and Mumbai, there have been brazen violations of the social distancing and lockdown norms by the people. What will be repercussions of this carelessness and is India ready to pay the price? 



“People are not understanding that government has done the unlocking, but Corona has not done the unlocking,” says Ravi Srivastava, Political Analyst


To what extent have the civic bodies, police and the state government been successful in controlling the spread, as much is left desired in cities recording a spike in COVID-19 cases on a daily basis. 



The legitimate question is what is the future of the country amid such brazen negligence? 



#CityCoronavirusCrisis

snippet.title: Jobs for migrant returnees: Centre's key scheme selected for few? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, The government's new employment scheme for returnee migrants, Garib Kalyan Rojgar Abhiyaan covers 116 districts in 6 states but Chhatisgarh and West Bengal have raised objection over not being included in the scheme.

The criteria being used to select States is being brought to question by the Non-BJP ruled states. Criteria are that one State should have a minimum of 25,000 Migrant Workers. There's no political aspect. State govt doesn't respond to the request of central govt: Sudesh Verma, BJP 

Clearly, it's discriminatory. It's a prospective scheme, as it's for the future. It doesn't immediately address the problems of Migrant Labourers, says, Anshul Avijit, Congress 

You should have rolled this scheme for all the Migrant Labourers across the board. Migrant Crisis is primarily created by the Centre, says, Monojit Mondal, TMC supporter on Chhatisgarh, West Bengal not being included in the Garib Kalyan Rojgar Abhiyaan Delhi is now the second worst-hit State in India, with 59,746 cases. 

Reporter Ayushmann did a ground-check in the Chandani Mahal area which is a containment zone & found appealing violations. Watch!

snippet.title: Can India fight back the China Cyberwarfare? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, new intels have informed India that Chinese hackers are trying to harm the business in the country and attack the systems. This attack is to weaken the Indian systems and stop the country from any development. The matter is of grave importance as Singaporean intel agencies have warned of malware attacks and other forms of cyberattacks on the country that aims to destabilize the economy.

 "It’s the first time in the history of Independent India that India’s nodal agency of Cyber Security has given this kind of a warning, and we need to take it far more seriously", says, Dr. Pavan Duggal, Cyber Law Expert.

snippet.title: Can India afford BLANKET BAN on Made in China? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, The importance of focussing on local Indian products has been the narrative for a really long time, but the dependency of India on China for a lot of products cannot be denied as well. The empowerment of Indian products, artists, and commodities is of utmost importance to make a difference.

Anything that will actually impact China will have to be a long-term policy, as the panel discusses. Empower the Indian businesses as it can't be a knee-jerk reaction!

We should be able to draw a fine line between nationalism & self-sufficiency. Going overboard & saying stop everything will hurt us more than Chin, says, Dinakar Peri, Defence Correspondent

Now, the government needs to put their foot down and take strict measures. One of the things that we can do to support our govt is to put on hold the contracts that we've been taking on, says, Clyde Crastro, NCP

The implementation on the ground, and what we talk, have to be the same. Per person import from China in 2014 was ₹3,000, now it has increased to ₹6,000. It has to be in our action, not only in words, says, Rohan Gupta, Congress

#BoycottChina

snippet.title: Will opposition stand with PM Modi against China? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, The All-party meet over the encroachment and recent Clash between India and China was held today. Major parties from across the country took part in the virtual meet and discussed with PM Modi on the issue. The developments in the meet were the major point of discussion throughout the country. 

Today there has been a little bit of clarity however, there are a lot more things that need to be cleared. We are saying that we will support the govt no matter what but tell us enough of what has happened, says, Aishwarya Mahadev, Congress

I would want to believe everything that our Prime Minister said today, but it fails the logic How did we lose 20 soldiers? We are not getting any clear communication as to what really happened, says Touseef A Khan, Political Analyst

The fact that within 2 days we called an All Party Meet where a detailed presentation was made & that the PM has stated that not an inch of our territory was intruded, explains everything, says BJP's Tuhin A Sinha

Standing united does not mean you don't question the govt, says Ravi Srivastava Founding member of AAP.

#AllPartyMeet

snippet.title: Corona cases do not seem to slow down, What is the reason? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, The cases of COVID-19 is rising at an alarming rate in Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, and Gujarat. The states haven't really shown any sign of a decrease in the recent future. While the country has had a unique approach towards tackling the same. Each state has its own story. 

Public Health Expert, Dr Abhay Shukla, says, for Maharashtra - a recent death audit showed that 76% of the cases had no known contact, & thus these were cases of #CommunityTransmission; case fatality rate is 3.7%.

According to the TIMES NETWORK Protiviti India Outbreak Report, by June 30, Delhi will see around 41,469 active #COVID cases. By July end, the cases will begin to drop. Dr. Harish Gupta of Delhi Medical Association says Delhi lacks awareness campaign. Chennai will see a peak by July 3, hitting around 21,000 active COVID cases.

Maharashtra is the state that is doing the highest number of testing. On March 31, the doubling rate was 3.5% and today it is 25.9%. We've cut down the price of testing by more than 50%: Cylde Castro, NCP spokesperson.

#IndiaOutbreakReport

snippet.title: India bids farewell to the martyrs, Will justice be brought to them? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, India bids adieu to the bravehearts who lost their lives fighting against the Chinese army. This incident has opened up a lot of debates about the policies of china and the central government’s work to safeguard the army from such violent incidents. 20 of our Bravehearts are no more. 20 of them who came from 11 states, spoke about 9 different languages but had one similarity, their unparalleled bravery. The stories of our Galwan Heroes are the ones that each one should know. India bows down to these heroes.

Each hero had a story, a family, a life and a home and all of that will miss them. Justice must be brought to them and policies should be framed so that no one has to go through this again. 


#GalwanHeroes

snippet.title: Has Galwan Valley historically been a big dispute with China? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, What will be the impact on other aspects of India-China ties? | The Urban Debate 

Leave matters military to the military. Don't ask them to defend the border when you are making them defenceless. Says Strategic Affairs Expert Maroof Raza.

Former Foreign Secretary Shashank says, It is essential that we change our policy in a fine nuanced basis & say that we will work with other Asian countries. 

Manu Pubby Senior Editor Economic Times, says, We have boosted our deployment & they have been boosted because of Chinese deployments. The Chinese can never be trusted; we can't really understand what they are up to. 

 Lt Gen Vinod Bhatia (Retd.), Former DGMO (Commanded corps along LAC): Let's have a strategy for the immediate term, for the mid-term and for long-term. We have to deter China's aggressive behaviour. 

Watch!

snippet.title: Decoding the Galwan Valley Battle in 10 different angles | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Each & every story of these 20 martyrs is equally painful & gut-wrenching & as you wrap up your day, send a prayer, send some wishes & send some strength to these families as the nation pays tribute to these Bravehearts.

Tanvi Shukla takes you through the latest developments WATCH the Urban Debate LIVE as experts answer 10 key questions.

On India China FaceOFF, Lt Gen DS Hooda (Retd.), Former Army Commander Northern Command says, We need to, at different levels, show our resolve. At the ground level, we need to militarily change our posture; we need to get much more tactical.


However, Ashok Sajjanhar Former Diplomat says, The stronger we are able to convey our posture on the border, the stronger we will be able to deal with the Chinese in political & diplomatic terms.

Snehesh Alex Philip Senior Associate Editor at The Print says, As per the current practice, none of the sides carry firearms. This is drawn from the 1996 agreement. However, now the authorities are reviewing the SOPs & the rules of engagement.

Lt Gen Sanjay Kulkarni (Retd) Former Corps Commander Ladakh says, The terrain on our side is extremely difficult; on the Chinese, though high altitude, the terrain is plain, so they can gather there. The point of application is what matters.

Former Diplomat Ashok Sajjanhar explains the geopolitical stakes in Indo-China relations. He further adds, How will this impact the Indo-China relations?

snippet.title: Why did China backstab despite agreement? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, India China Face Off | 
she takes you through the sequence of events that led up to the India China Clash, India China Standoff, and India China Border.

Manu Pubby Senior Editor of Economic Times says, This clash is almost unprecedented. We haven't seen anything like this since 1967 perhaps. We need to bring in some restraint or higher-level intervention on India China Face-Off at the India China Border. 

Maj. General Ashok K. Mehta (Retd) explains why the Galwan Valley is an area of high importance. He also says that we have a situation where the troops may pull back from 1 or 2 intrusions but will not pull back from the Galwan river valley.

snippet.title: India-China biggest escalation, 90 minutes, 10 angles explained | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
Tonight on The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, one of the biggest escalations in the last 45-years, MIRROR NOW focuses on this violent India-China clash and answers 10 BIG Questions which decodes India China Stand-Off.

BREAKING: MEA reacts to India-China clash saying:
-Discussions on between India & China
-Talks are on to de-escalate the situation
-China departed from consensus to respect LAC at Galwan Valley
-Clash as the Chinese side attempted to change the status quo. 

India wants to signal that just because we're adopting a posture of seeking disengagement & de-escalation, it doesn't mean that we'll not hold our ground. Says Former Diplomat Meera Shankar on MEA's statement over India-China Face-Off. 

Galwan Valley has largely been a peaceful area, since 1962. It is not really the place where we see the skirmishes along the LAC, but that seems to have changed this time. Explains Retired Army Chief General Shankar Roy Chowdhury. 

 A lot of efforts taken to defuse the situation, but with China, it’s just so unpredictable. Nowhere else will you hear two countries agree to de-escalate and then end up in such a violent clash Tanvi Shukla questions Strategic Affairs Expert Maroof Raza. 

Militarily, how does it work on-ground as the LAC isn't clear? What's usually the system as far as Ladakh is concerned? Former Corps Commander of Ladakh, LT Gen PJS Pannu explains. 
 
Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Sushant Singh's death unveils dark side of Bollywood; Was it suicide or murder? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, we discuss Sushant Singh Rajput's death which has triggered a series of debates & many skeletons seem to be tumbling out from the Bollywood industry. The debate panel speaks about the cruel side of the glamour & glitz.
Actor Meera Chopra says "Since yesterday, more than sad I am angry that I am a part of an industry that at times becomes so ruthless & cold. At the end of the day, you will always remain an outsider. Nobody is your friend. You are constantly judged."
Filmmaker Akashdeep Sabir says "Bollywood is a line that is full of pressure. Every Friday changes the status quo of people. The struggle, the desire to be part of the successful brigade probably gets you from inside but it's not to do with bad people. It is the nature of the business."

snippet.title: Delhi's real COVID death toll double of reported toll? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, INVESTIGATION -- MIRROR NOW has accessed EXCLUSIVE documents which reveals massive discrepancies in death toll numbers reported by the Delhi govt and civic body, MCD.

There are 3 arms that contribute to data. Pvt-Govt. hospitals, civic body & a centralised agency, under the State govt. Lack of cohesion between the three is too stark. Says Vinay Tewari Mirror Now's Managing Editor.

Till now, we've around 2,600 death certificates available. We've been saying that the death rate in Delhi is very high, but no one was ready to accept this. Says Bhupender Gupta SDMC South Delhi Municipal Corporation. 

If they went in for opening up of the economy, they should've been ready for better medical & hospital facilities. Both Govts have let us down, they had 2.5 months. Says Neerja Chowdhury Sr. Journalist.

Why don’t we have a clear answer on this, the discrepancy is huge, double the deaths that are being reported by the government? Tanvi Shukla questions to Aam Aadmi Party's Saurabh Bharadwaj.

On May 16, Delhi health secretary wrote a letter to all 3 municipal corporations to verify the data regarding total deaths. In our responses on 17, it was clear that there's a difference in State & MCD nos. but Delhi govt still didn't wake up. Says Jai Prakash North MCD. 

Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Sushant Singh Rajput's death jolts India; What triggered him to drown his life? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate today, leading Success Coach, Anand Chulani and Psychiatrist & Author, Dr Anjali Chhabria discusses on the sudden demise of Bollywood Actor Sushant Singh Rajput and what might have triggered him to drown his life to death.

Sushant Singh Rajput, a 34-year-old actor and India’s heartthrob committed suicide by hanging himself at his residence in Bandra. He was well known for his acting performances in TV serial ‘Pavitra Rishta’ and many other movies like ‘MS Dhoni’, ‘Chhichhore’, ‘Kai Po Che’ and many more.

snippet.title: Delhi reports 7000+ cases in 5 days, Is it India's new crisis zone? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Delhi has been noticing a faulty healthcare system and infrastructure. There have been 7,000 cases reported in the last 5 days and the Supreme Court has issued a notice seeking Delhi government's response to the inadequate health facilities provided to the people. 

Mirror Now did a ground check and witnessed shocking violations in the areas which were supposed to be strictly monitored. Jhangirpuri district in Delhi is one of the worst-hit areas in Delhi.

The country has been seeing a thousand cases every day and the testing rate has decreased.

COVID-19 exposed the faulty healthcare system in the country and both State and Central governments should act together during this time. Delhi cannot fight COVID alone and the Centre should come forward and help, says senior journalist Javed Mansari.

snippet.title: Inhumane stories of COVID deaths, Will India reinvent a new system? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the issue of treating dead bodies inhumanely was discussed. The crumbling healthcare system and the inadequate measures taken by the hospitals talks a lot about how the country has dealt with COVID-19 deaths. 

Hospitals are found not giving basic respect to dead bodies and various stories have emerged that talk about how the hospitals deny dignity in death. 

Dr. Mahesh Chandra Misra, Former Director, AIIMS talks about how there exists sheer negligence, unpreparedness on the part of the administration. There has been nothing in place except for creating more beds for people. All of the crisis happened when the country had a low death rate. 

Dr. Sanjeev Bagai, Chairman, Nephron Clinics explains how there is a complete crush of humanity. The lockdown was initiated for preparedness and the measures must be taken on a war footing. The system should be reinvented by the people.

snippet.title: Schooling in COVID era, Are online classes the right solution? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the online exam dilemma was discussed as students in India are going through a tough time, not only battling the virus but also managing their studies via online methods. Karnataka government has banned online classes for students till class 6 until they do deeper research and figure out a way forward. 

There has to be a dialogue on reconstructing learning experiences where the school isn't the only agent of that. We need to look at multifarious modes available, says Psychologist, Dr. Geetanjali Kumar.
To what extent can the government ensure that everybody has access to the internet and a screen good enough for a student to be glued for several hours, especially in rural areas, questions Ali Sait, CEO Tech. 

Seema Dharmadas who is a parent talks about how she has tried a few apps during the lockdown since there was no teacher, there was hardly any interactivity noticed.

snippet.title: COVID healthcare system crumbling, Nightmare for the patients? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the Indian health facilities were discussed. The ground reality comes as shocking news with the way India has been dealing with the Covid-19 pandemic. The governments are now being questioned the way they maintained their crumbling healthcare system of the country. One of the incidents that came was how an elderly woman who tested positive for COVID-19 was seen crying in agony, helplessly waiting for treatment at the gate of a government hospital in Jalgaon.

This hospital came in the news as an 82-year-old woman was found dead in the toilet. Another such incident that was highlighted from Jalgaon was when a mother kept waiting for 6 hours for an ICU bed, says a resident from Jalgaon who lost his mother to COVID-19. His grandmother was admitted to the same hospital and went missing from the ward. Her body was then found in the hospital toilet after 8 days. 

A journalist named Manoj was tested positive for COVID and was admitted to Hyderabad's Gandhi Hospital. His brother says that he had to fight with doctors to move him to ICU but there was a delay because there were no oxygen cylinders. Manoj died of a cardiac arrest on June 7.

snippet.title: COVID-19 Report Card: How your City is performing? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
With coronavirus cases going up at a rapid rate, are big cities to be blamed for the rise as they fail to tackle the situation? Mumbai, Ahmadabad, Delhi, Bengaluru, Kolkata marks the maximum number of cases. Today we bring in the projections by different states. How the curve of COVID-19 cases moves in these big cities. 
Ahmadabad being reporting the maximum number of cases around it has managed to control the rate and has increased its recovery rate by manifold. Whereas on the other had Delhi, Mumbai continues to suffer Even after many precautions taken by the Delhi government, the Lieutenant governor the cases continue to rise. Mumbai, which was taking the lead since the beginning, is now finally narrowing down on the cases. 
The panel further discusses and put their views forward on the pandemic.

snippet.title: COVID-19 Report Card: Is your State winning or lagging the war?  | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the data on the India outbreak report of Coronavirus was shared by the Managing Director of Mirror Now, Mr. Vinay Tewari. It coved various metropolitan cities and how they have been tackling with the pandemic. It shows both the correct and incorrect measures taken by the states and cities.

Where Kerala was seen doing a great job at containing the pandemic, the only concern now is  the recovery rate and the active number of COVID-19 cases, says Dr. Padmanabha Shenoy, Rheumatologist

Tamil Nadu on the other hand is targeting to find symptomatic cases and handling them. The government is said to increase the number of beds provided, says Dr. J Rajkunar, Consultant- Pediatric infectious diseases,Chennai

Despite the High Court giving an order, Gujarat government has not focused much on private testing of COVID-19 cases.

Andhra Pradesh has also noticed considerable low deaths in the state.

snippet.title: Exams dilemma nationwide, Boards ready but students confused? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, exam dilemma amid the Coronavirus crisis is a major issue faced by a lot of students, while the cases keep increasing in the country, Tamil Nadu has joined the list of states who have cancelled class 10th Board Exams. There's a nationwide exam dilemma as states vary. Whether there should be uniform policies for the pending exams is the current question being discussed. 

When the lockdown was initiated, there were approximately 500 cases detected, exams were then postponed, now that the nation has witnessed more than 2 lakh COVID-19 cases, exams shouldn't be rescheduled as it is not a good idea, says Suvashwin who is a student.

The important question is how long will students sit at home, getting scared, as the initial lockdown was because they needed time to prepare. Now that students, boards and parents are getting ready for the examination is important for children, says Ranjini Krishnaswamy, Director of Dosti Foundation Schools.

localized.title: Exams dilemma nationwide, Boards ready but students confused? | The Urban Debate
localized.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, exam dilemma amid the Coronavirus crisis is a major issue faced by a lot of students, while the cases keep increasing in the country, Tamil Nadu has joined the list of states who have cancelled class 10th Board Exams. There's a nationwide exam dilemma as states vary. Whether there should be uniform policies for the pending exams is the current question being discussed. 

When the lockdown was initiated, there were approximately 500 cases detected, exams were then postponed, now that the nation has witnessed more than 2 lakh COVID-19 cases, exams shouldn't be rescheduled as it is not a good idea, says Suvashwin who is a student.

The important question is how long will students sit at home, getting scared, as the initial lockdown was because they needed time to prepare. Now that students, boards and parents are getting ready for the examination is important for children, says Ranjini Krishnaswamy, Director of Dosti Foundation Schools.

snippet.title: Delhi Govt predicts COVID cases till July, A fear-mongering or impending crisis? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the health status of the Coronavirus pandemic in Delhi is discussed. The Delhi government has projected that the National Capital may have 5.5 lakh COVID-19 cases by the end of July and 80,000 beds will be needed to treat the patients infected.

Akshay Marathe from Aam Aadmi Party talks about the estimation is projected by the end of July and the numbers are put out so there's consensus on whether to determine if community transmission exists. He later talks about the factors that are taken into consideration to determine this estimation.

The Chairman of IMA Hospital, Dr. V K Monga admits that there is an extensive rate of community transmission in Delhi and Mumbai which has led to higher COVID-19 cases.

Dr. Devinder Singh Rana, Chairman, Sir Ganga Ram Hospital also explains how fear of rising COVID-19 cases should be a concern for the Delhi govt and the central govt to start constructing COVID dedicated hospitals. Watch the video to know more!

snippet.title: Delhi draws battle lines over COVID treatment, Time for uniform policy? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, there have been various incidents emerging of confrontation between the states and private hospitals. The idea of the debate was to resolve the existing policies for COVID hospitals to either make uniform policies for all. 

Dr. Raj B Singh, Pulmonologist, Apollo Hospital, Chennai said that in a country like India, 90% of healthcare should be provided from public funding because it is our underinvestment that has produced great shortages which are now being filled in by private medicines. 

Akshay Marathe from Aam Aadmi Party talks about how black marketing of beds has taken over the pandemic in our country. There should be proper checking of private hospitals in the country and a sustainable system should be built to tackle the illness.

The question of whether the government should step in, and subsidize some part of the cost of private hospitals is still a concern for many.
Watch!

snippet.title: RWA impose unfounded restrictions amid COVID, How far is too far? I The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Resident Welfare Associations take law into their own hands. Dictate bizarre rules to keep COVID in check. Here is a list of some of these incidents. Is RWA imposing unfounded laws onto your society?

RWAs must understand their limitations. They have to work for the convenience of the people but they have no business to take law in their own hands says KK Rai, Senior SC Advocate 

Find out what you can do if you are a victim of these unprecedented restrictions by housing societies. 

The Delhi government has responded to the Mirror Now investigation which revealed the data mismatch of hospital beds and ventilator availability in its Delhi Corona App. AAP has deflected the blame to the hospitals saying it is them who are irregular with updating the information.

snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, BJP leader & Tik Tok star, Sonali Phogat speaks to TIMES NETWORK giving clarification about the incident. She said she lost her cool because the man had passed lewd remarks at her which no woman could possibly tolerate.

The biggest challenge for Delhi is, instead of reducing the number of testing, we have to increase this exponentially. The W.H.O too has stressed on testing since the beginning. says, AIIMS Former Director Dr. Mahesh Chandra Misra.

Mumbai’s doubling period has been consistently increasing, it's 15.7 now. However, now that people have gone to other districts, it's going to be a challenge to look at the spread in those parts says, Mumbai School of Economics & Public Policy Prof. Neeraj Hatekar.

snippet.title: Will buying homes be cheaper? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, According to a newspaper report, Union Minister Piyush Goyal told the builders that they have no other choice but to sell at realistic prices & that they shouldn't expect any support. Will buying homes be cheaper? 

The govt fund cannot be allowed to go into projects that are unsustainable. These projects become unsustainable because of their high prices. says, BJP's Sudesh Verma.

In the past few weeks, WHO has changed its stand on the #COVID drug trial, its stand on Hydroxychloroquine. Why this back & forth? What is happening? 

It is easy to say 'sell at a lower price' but will my lender give me a NOC? If I don't get the NOC, how do I register the apartment in the name of the buyer? Nobody is talking about the technical aspect. says, Raheja Developers Chairman & MD Naveen Raheja.

Watch!

snippet.title: AAP alleges mismatch of COVID data, Bickering returns to Delhi politics? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, AAP has accused the Centre-run RML Hospital of wrongful testing; says Delhi government re-tested 30 positive samples from the hospital, 12 were found negative & 2 inconclusive. Is politics taking precedence over COVID in Delhi? Is testing data mismatch intentional or procedural?

There is a scientific scope for variation in the results from day to day basis. The virus titre can also differ in the patient because the immune system is fighting, says, Dr Rakesh Mishra, Director, Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology.

Quality is something that the ICMR or NIV should take a call on, whether it is right or wrong. Whom to test, that the govt can take a call on, says, Dr Arokiaswamy Velumani, Chairman & MD, Thyrocare Technologies Ltd.

Farmers in Kerala use bait bombs to prevent wild boars from entering their farms. Unfortunately, any animal ends up eating it. The onus lies on the government for designing & implementation of a policy to solve this problem.

#DelhiPoliticsOverCOVID  #KeralaElephantDeath

snippet.title: Unlock 1.0 is here, Is it too soon to end lockdown & open schools? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, While the country is easing restrictions as far as lockdown is concerned, there has been no decision on reopening of schools yet. But, the conversation has begun. Is it safe to reopen schools now? Are schools ready to tackle COVID?

We cannot have an all India policy for the opening of schools. We have to take into consideration the districts, where are the students coming from, says, Lipika Nanda, Vice President, Multi-Sectorial Planning in Public Health, PHFI

When we make decisions about the opening of schools, we have to keep in mind that we are going to open ourselves up for the spread of infection via the kids. It is going to be a risk-benefit calculus, says, Anant Bhan, Researcher, Global Health, Bioethics & Health Policy. 

#LivingWithCovid

snippet.title: Cyclone Nisarga hits Mumbai, did the city fare well? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, The cyclone Nisarga changed its course just before its landfall, thus doing minimum damage to Mumbai city. The BMC’s estimate of electricity lines getting snapped did not happen. 
Reporter Mayuresh and Disha Shah provide the latest updates from ground zero. 

The upper steering currents are responsible for steering the cyclone towards north and north-east, or 10-20-degree further east, which we have seen this time. There is sometimes an error of judgment. In this case, the error margin was 30 km, says, Mahesh Palawat, VP, Sky Met Weather. 

In Kerala the farmers use crackers wrapped with jaggery to target wild boars. This is the first time I’m hearing such a method of injuring an elephant, says, Surendrakumar, Chief Wildlife Warden, Kerala Forest Department 

In the State of Kerala, there are over 600 captive elephants who suffer unheard. The State really needs to re-look at the way it treats its elephants altogether, says, Ambika Hiranandani, Animal Rights Activist.

#CycloneNisarga #ElephantDeath

snippet.title: Delhi hospitals' COVID rate card expose, Is treatment a business? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Another investigation by Mirror Now, reports from the national capital, our correspondent made the calls in 5 different private hospitals in the city Delhi. & everywhere there was a steep cost & a catch for COVID admission.

These dysfunctional charges are baffling. It is unfair. This is putting medical treatment, even in times of a pandemic, out of reach for almost everyone. says, Chairman of Nephron Clinics  Sanjeev Bagai.

IMA has been demanding that the govt set up a system of costing for all levels of working in various hospitals all across the country. So many issues come up when costing studies are done. says,  Chairman of IMA hospital board of India Dr V K Monga.

Manu Sharma, convict in the 1999 Jessica Lal murder case, gets premature release after the Delhi L-G approved the same. Are rules for early release uniform? Is early release a benefit of the privileged? Should Manu Sharma have been released?

#CovidInvestigation

snippet.title: Cyclone Nisarga hits Mumbai, Is City ready for another fight? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, the reality of the excavation of the cyclone is exposed in Mumbai. Reporter Santia Gora gets a ground report from Palghar, where people are being moved to shelter homes.

Mumbai Civic Body’s evacuation process only on paper. Reporter Disha Shah gets a report from Versova beach where people living just 10m away from the beach are yet to be relocated. Even children were seen playing by the sea

The State Govt has promised that the evacuation of people from low lying areas will take place, even if this has to take place throughout the night. Evacuation is the key to the entire preparation for the cyclone, says, SN Pradhan, DG, NDRF

The wind speeds can lead to structural damages such as damage to hoardings etc. in the city. Rail and road communication will be affected because of the strong winds and heavy rainfall, as will air transport because of the unstable atmosphere, says, Dr. Mrutyunjay Mohapatra, DG, IMD.

#CycloneNisarga

snippet.title: Unlock 1.0 is here, are states ready to tackle increase in COVID-19 cases? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, As India steps out with restrictions being lifted, the question remains if the states are ready? Will implementing precautionary measures be the biggest challenge? Has India used the lockdown well to build the health infrastructure?

We need to enhance public support & for that, you need clarity of purpose. The other thing is, some of the guidelines are confusing & the lack of agreement between Centre & states is also not helping. Says, Researcher, Global Health, Bioethics, & Health Policy, Anant Bhan. 

We admit that there were instances of people not being able to find beds but it was due to lack of information. Tomorrow onwards we will be launching a web dashboard on which any person can find out which hospital has how many beds & ventilators. says, Media Panelist, Aam Aadmi Party, Akshay Marathe

The first 2 lockdowns were very successful in containing the spread of the disease significantly. But the testing still has to go up so that those who are COVID positive be put under strict quarantine. says, Former Director of AIIMS , Dr Mahesh Chandra Misra 

#Unlock1IsHere

snippet.title: Lockdown 5.0 brings relaxation but citizens facing issues due to lack of clarity? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Mirror Now reporters from across the country are reporting live regarding the ground situation. Reporter Prashant Kumar gets us a ground report from Delhi’s famous Sarojni Nagar market. As markets have been given permission to open, small shop traders are facing problems as there has been no clarity from the government. Traffic snarls continue as the rules for traffic movement are not clear yet.
Reporter Sreeja MS brings a report on the situation on the ground in Bengaluru. As India opens up, there are a number of relaxations in the lockdown norms that have been allowed. Reporter Pramod Madhav on the situation in Chennai following the relaxations of lockdown norms. Chennai continues to be one of the worst affected cities.

It's a 50-50 battle for this country right now. The war against COVID-19 & the reality of opening up to revive the economy, can’t be one unless both, the citizens and the Govt play their part. or we will lose it quickly, says, Vinay Tewari, Managing Editor, Mirror Now.

#NoClarityonRestrictions

snippet.title: India begins phase 1 of unlocking, what will be the life after Lockdown 4.0? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On the weekend edition of The Urban Debate, as we near lockdown 4.0's end which is tomorrow we have already got some details of what life could look like starting from June 1st 2020. 
A lot of this will depend on the state governments as the centre has given the state government to make rules according to the severity of the Coronavirus cases in the cities of these states.
What will be the regulations for the containment zone? 
The centre has started begin the first phase of unlocking India after 2 months of complete lockdown. The centre is finally willing to open up the cities from the 8th of June which is next Monday. 
As India begins phase 1 of unlocking, what will be the life after Lockdown 4.0?

snippet.title: Mumbai hospitals lack beds, Is the Maha govt capable of handling Corona anymore? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Mirror Now uncovers the lack of beds in the hospitals in Mumbai in the face of the corona pandemic. The reality is sad and patients are suffering. 

Reporters Disha Shah and Alok Singh called up some of the top hospitals in #Mumbai, to enquire about the availability of ICU beds only to found out there is a 5-6 day waiting period. 

With the number of patients increasing every day in thousands in the state of Maharashtra, the hospitals lack ICU beds and it has been exposed by Mirror Now. 

"We are working on all levels. We are trying to arrange everything. Very soon, we won't have this problem," says NCP's SeemaMalik in response to Mirror Now's exposé on non-availability of beds for COVID patients  

#NobedsforCovidpatients

snippet.title: Supreme Court passes order for migrants, Will it help in containing the mess? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Puling up Centre & States for leaving the migrants to fend for themselves, SC issues slew of directions; says migrants should not be charged for bus or train and food & water should be provided. Mirror Now take you through what happened in the top court today.

Firoz & his family of 24 reached Mumbai's Sion this morning after he got a call saying there will be a train leaving for his hometown. However, after waiting for almost 4 hours, for transportation, they were asked to leave.

The Centre issues guidelines & works on that. We have more than 5 crore migrants. These kinds of issues arise because of a certain kind of rush. We have to be slightly more vigilant at the ground level," says, BJP's Gopal Krishna Agarwal.

snippet.title: Worst Locust attack in 26 year, Impact on us & what needs to be done? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla,  This is the worst locust attack in 26 years and it could lead to a national agricultural disaster. Whatever, steps need to be taken, must be taken now. Why is this happening? What kind of preparations do we need?

National Coordinator of Rashtriya Kisan Mahasangh Abhimanyu Kohar explains what could be the possible impact of the Locust Attack.

This problem has just begun & it could go on for another 4-5 months. These swarms need to be controlled at the border districts. The States and the Centre have to coordinate on a daily basis. says, Bharat Krishak Samaj Chairman Ajay Vir Jakhar.

Watch the top developments of the ongoing India-China standoff.

"Since the beginning of this month, Chinese troops have now come in set up camp in areas which were just patrolled". Listen in as Senior Editor of Economic Times Manu Pubby explains what is happening at the India-China border & how the situation is different from the past.

#LocustAttack

snippet.title: Mumbai says ready for COVID battle but reality is something else? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, 10 hospitals, same answer: No beds available. All 10 hospitals said no ICU beds available & one of the biggest hospitals said they didn't have enough ventilators. What has been done in the last two months? 

Any patient who is showing symptoms is not supposed to call the hospitals directly. A dashboard system has been evolved. Patients are supposed to call on the numbers given, then BMC will a lot a bed. says,  NCP Sanjay Tatkare.

We have enough number of instances of to show how people have been struggling to get beds and ambulances & you are asking us to check the dashboard that wasn't even live as of 7 PM this evening? says, Tanvi Shukla to NCP's Sanjay Tatkare.

There was a scarcity of beds. 4-5 days ago, all doctors had a meeting with CM, Municipal Commissioner & Chief Secretary. We have increased more than 500 ICU beds & more than 3000 beds from private hospitals side. says, Member of Maharashtra task force for Covid-19 Dr Gautam Bhansali.

#MumbaiMessExposed

snippet.title: How Migrants sufffer in Centre-State crossfire | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Migrants & the huge mess that has happen over the trains that was suppose take this migrants back to home. 

Railways is a very old, large & professional organisation and all this makes them look like a joke which they are not. They are a very efficient organization. I really think, that at the root of all this is indecisive and whimsical politician. says, Yogendra Yadav. 

In your experience, does this look like a complicated job? Yes, it will be difficult to decide who will be in those trains but, how can we not give them water and food? Tanvi Shukla asks to Former Add'l Member Railway Board Vijay Kumar Dutt.

The 200 trains that will start in June, will those people go hungry as well or is it this just a special treatment that we have for our migrants? Tanvi Shukla asks to BJP's Shweta Shalini.

snippet.title: Is Mumbai's Corona crisis a massive strategy failure? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, The biggest challenge in India will be Mumbai. It already has a large number of cases, it has a huge & high-density population. Are the measures being taken enough? Is the city headed towards a massive failure? 

People have been taking COVID-19 casually. Guidelines are being issued, but there is an issue in implementation. For the past 2 months, I haven't seen a vigilance committee. says, Member of IMA National COVID Task Force Dr Mangesh Pate.

The Police & the Mumbai Civic Body are ensuring that the guidelines are implemented, but there are people who just don't seem to listen. The onus is also on the people to understand that this is a severe pandemic. says, NCP's Clyde Crasto.

If people are coming out on to the streets even after a #Lockdown, what is the govt doing? What is the police doing? If the police cannot handle it then call the army, call the SRP. says, BJP's Ram Kadam.

Watch!

snippet.title: Anger at Airports & Stations, Who is responsible for the chaos? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Anger at airports & stations. Utter mayhem & confusion. Every state going on its own tangent leaving it to the passengers to figure out how they should travel. Who is responsible for the chaos?

"States do not want to solve the problems of the migrants or the people who want to go back home", says BJP's Gopal Krishna Agarwal. Tanvi Shukla responds; says if the onus was just on states, the Centre would not need to issue a circular saying we will curtail the number of flights.

The blame has to be on the Centre. Before releasing the SOP they should have made sure that all the states are on the same line. They should have had better coordination . says, TRS Mahesh Bigala.

#DomesticTravel

snippet.title: Flying domestic but information about flights unclear? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla,  Day of chaos & confusion at the biggest airports in India. Refunds, Protocols, Public transport worries. Top experts answer your questions on post COVID travel. 

Delhi Airport sees 125 departures & 40 cancellations on Day 1 of resumption of domestic flights. While social distancing & other rules were followed, what was missing was the coordination between passengers & the airlines. Mirror Now Ayushmann  gets the latest updates.

Mirror Now Neha Kulkarni speaks to a passenger who reached Mumbai at around 7 PM this evening and is still waiting at the airport because there is no way for him to get back home. The vehicles that are willing to ferry him and his family are charging exorbitantly.

Where is the consolidated policy? It has just been left to the states who are waking up whenever they feel like. Should this not have been clearer from day 1? The governments first failed our migrants & now those who want to go back home.

#ConfusionOverFlights

snippet.title: Why India must strictly adopt the new lifestyle? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, It was the first week of a relaxed Lockdown in India & there's a rampant violation of all kind of norms. In just 48 hours, over 7 incidents from across the country, where Lockdown norms, especially social distancing were violated.

Apart from people being themselves responsible, do policies need to be designed in a certain manner to ensure that Lockdown norms are followed?

Don't put blame on Centre as it has given a lot of liberty to States: BJP's Sudesh Verma responds to AAP's Dr Ajoy Kumar.

We had almost 2-months of Lockdown period and that should have been used to devise a strategy. Now, isn't the time to discuss that. says, Tanvi Shukla.

snippet.title: Why West Bengal needs our urgent support? | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, With more than 10 lakh houses completely destroyed, more than 1.36 crore people affected, &death toll increasing to 86 Mirror Now Tamal Saha gives us an update on the devastation caused by Cyclone Amphan in West Bengal.

I’m glad that the country is finally waking up to the magnitude of this National disaster. I would like to tip my hat to the endless number of people working tirelessly to bring things back to normalcy, right from the public works Dept, the police and others. says, Actor Param Brata.

We need all the support, keeping politics aside because this is a super cyclone in the time of a pandemic. We need all the help to save Bengal. says,  Comedian Anirban Dasgupta.

snippet.title: Airplane, train services to resume; How will travel change in the post COVID era? |The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate, we focus on travel and domestic travel. The government has decided to restart air travel operations from Monday the 25th of May 2020. The government has also decided on starting roughly 200 more trains which will begin from the 1st of June. This all is happening even though India is still in lockdown 
How will travel change in the post COVID era?

Former MD of Air India, Ashwani Lohani & Delhi International Airport Ltd. CEO Videh Kumar Jaipuriar debate on this!

Mirror Now News Editor Tanvi Shukla also spoke to Manoj Sinha, former MoS Railways. Listen in to know more!

snippet.title: Cyclone Amphan aftermath, trail of destruction amidst COVID-19 scare | The Urban Debate
snippet.description:
On The Urban Debate with Tanvi Shukla, Parts of Kolkata has no electricity, no drinking water. Houses after houses completely ravished, school building boundaries fallen down, hundreds of trees uprooted. Mirror Now Tamal Saha  LIVE from South 24 Parganas, tells us about the situation on ground, post Cyclone Amphan.

Randeep Kumar Rana, DIG (Operations), NDRF gives us an idea about the extent of damage in West Bengal, after Cyclone Amphan made a landfall in the state yesterday.

We were told the policy have changed, people are being home quarantined & number of beds have increased then why are hospitals still struggling to admit patients? Why are we not being able to confront this problem time and again? Tanvi Shukla asks to  Congress' Charan Singh Sapra.

Watch!
